PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should—
request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability

TAB.TAB: protected our liberties and freedoms

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a)establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b)limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c)control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d)increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a)outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b)lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c)cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned,

PETITION.PARA: (i)are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.
(ii)call on the Senate to express its total opposition to the introduction of a consumption (goods and services) tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate will, as a matter of urgency, establish a Committee of inquiry into
(a)the export of Australian military hardware and services;

PETITION.PARA: (b)the adequacy of existing controls over Australian arms exports;
(c)the implications of the international arms trade and ways in which it might be reduced.

PARA.TAB: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:

PETITION.PARA: request the Australian Government to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish—

PARA.TAB: the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)condemns the Government for its economic mismanagement and policy failures which have resulted in the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s;

(b)notes with great concern that Australians, over the period of the Hawke Government, have seen their living standards eroded, their tax burden rise, their families subjected to increasing pressures as unemployment escalates, the foreign debt climb, record bankruptcies, their health system in crisis and their education system eroded;
(c)recognises the opportunity that the Coalition's package of economic reforms gives to Australians to regain responsibility and control of their lives and to rebuild this great nation; and

(d)calls on the Government to support the Coalition's undertaking to identify the problems facing Australia and develop a comprehensive, detailed and integrated program of reform to address these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes the recall of both Houses of Parliament on 2 January 1992, during the middle of the summer adjournment, to hear an address from the President of the United States (Mr Bush) before a formal sitting of the Parliament, which is in keeping with American tradition but not Australian tradition;

(b)calls on the Government to cancel this totally unnecessary exercise and subservience, thus allowing President Bush to have a longer game of golf with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which should prove far more enjoyable for both of them, as well as saving the Australian taxpayers at least a couple of million dollars; and
Senator Macdonald—You don't have your supporters here today, and you won't be here anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will still be here. I am still a senator until 31 January. I will be boycotting it; do not worry.

PARA.TAB: (c)suggests to families of parliamentarians that they encourage a boycott of this event so that they can have the Christmas and New Year period free of yet another onerous trip to Canberra, and at the same time win some credit points in the community for resisting this unacceptable extravagance in the face of recession and unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I should point out to the Senate that we have not yet agreed to the motion to come back.
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)welcomes the `Fightback' package of proposals announced by the Liberal and National parties to rebuild and reward Australia including, in particular:

TAB.TAB: (i)the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history, amounting to $13 billion,
(ii)the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, petroleum products excise, superannuation lump sum tax, customs duty, training guarantee levy and the coal export duty,
(iii)significant, and beneficial, restructuring of the capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax,
(iv)the creation of two million jobs,
(v)a halving of the current devastating level of unemployment and underemployment involving more than 1.5 million Australians, and
(vi)the introduction of a 15 per cent goods and services tax that will:
(A)reform and simplify Australia's grossly inefficient taxation system,
(B)boost our national productivity and savings,
(C)enable greater international competitiveness by slashing taxes on business inputs,
(D)assist in reducing marginal tax rates and thus increase incentives to work, save and invest,
(E)make the tax system fairer by reducing avoidance and evasion, and
(F)adequately compensate Australians for the net one-off price effect of the goods and services tax package;

PARA.TAB: (b)congratulates the Liberal and National parties for providing hope, and a vision for the future, for all Australians; and

(c)calls upon the Hawke Government to show similar vision, and provide similar hope, to the millions of Australians whose jobs have been lost and whose living standards, and future prospects, have fallen so savagely as a result of the worst recession that has occurred in Australia for 60 years as the inevitable and deliberate outcome of the Government's massive economic policy failures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes the shift in Government policy on East Timor announced on 26 November 1991;

(b)expresses its dismay that the resolution accepts the continuing sale of arms to, and training of, Indonesian armed forces, and only seeks to review this policy in the light of the Indonesian Government's investigation into the Dili massacre;

(c)notes that the Indonesian armed forces are almost exclusively dedicated to maintaining internal control and that there is a reasonable risk that military goods and services from Australia will be used against Indonesian citizens in violation of their human rights;

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the implementation of pharmaceutical restructuring measures be extended to 26 February 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to that notice.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has held four days of public hearings in this inquiry. It will be taking further evidence tonight in public session as it was unable to complete its proposed program at its hearing on 15 November. The evidence which has emerged from submissions and from the public hearings indicates that the issues are more complex than was apparent at the time of reference by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The Committee proposes to present an interim report to the Senate on the progress of the inquiry before the end of this session. This report will provide some background to the inquiry and raise the issues that have emerged. The subsequent report will deal with the implementation of the pharmacy restructuring process and related matters which have been raised during the inquiry. The Committee therefore seeks the deferral of the presentation of its report until 26 February 1991.

(b)commends the Board of Management for retaining the aims and objectives for which the College was established; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the shift in Government policy on East Timor announced on 26 November 1991;
(b)expresses its concern that the resolution calls only for exploration of the role which the United Nations (UN) might now play in relation to East Timor;

(c)notes that this is a weaker position than has been taken by the Government on other recent conflicts, such as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the war in Yugoslavia, where full support was given to an active UN role; and
(d)calls on the Australian Government to propose and lobby for a full UN investigation of the Dili massacre, and the active involvement of the UN in the just resolution of the conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a)its slow response in providing a legislative base to the industry statement of 12 March 1991;
(b)its failure to simplify Australia's taxation laws;
(c)its failure to implement just and adequate penalties in a new tax environment of self-assessment;
(d)its creation of unnecessary tax avoidance by not equating the corporate tax rate with the top marginal tax rate; and
(e)its failure to remove from taxation law impediments to Australian business in competing in an international environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the shift in Government policy on East Timor announced on 26 November 1991;

(b)points out that Indonesian human rights abuses are not confined to East Timor, and that the denial of those rights by the military-backed Jakarta dictatorship extends across the Indonesian archipelago; and

(c)calls on the Government to reassess its position on other areas of conflict, such as Irian Jaya, or West Papua, and to craft a principled policy on human rights, rather than ignoring problems until they erupt in full view of the international media.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Opposition's `Fightback' package contains proposals to give superannuation opportunities to women who are not in the paid workforce and a much better deal for those women who are in casual, part-time or temporary employment,
(ii)the package entitles older women who have been out of the workforce to make tax deductible `catch-up' contributions to their superannuation,
(iii)it also allows women to work on past pension age in exchange for an increased pension if they so desire, and
(iv)despite nearly nine years of Labor's ruling Australian women, retirement income needs have not been addressed; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Government for substituting rhetoric for action when it comes to helping women.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the hesitant shift in Government policy on East Timor announced on 26 November 1991;

(b)expresses its shame and anger that this change was forced on the Government only because the Dili massacre, unlike the many previous acts of repression of the East Timorese and other minorities by Indonesian forces, was conducted in full view of Western journalists;

(c)condemns the Hawke, Fraser and Whitlam Governments for having played their part in prolonging the suffering of the East Timorese people by clinging to an unjust and unworkable policy of sycophantic appeasement since 1975;

(d)notes that this so-called `pragmatic' policy has failed, in that it could not prevent the inevitable deterioration in bilateral relations over human rights which has been precipitated by the Dili massacre; and
(e)calls on the Government to recognise the rights of the people of East Timor to self-determination and to take urgent steps to bring about the independence of East Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the tax and economic reform package announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in the week beginning 17 November 1991 has been widely supported by Australia's largest accounting firms, including Arthur Anderson & Co, Coopers and Lybrand and Ernst & Young, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

(c)expresses the view that the Australian Government's policy of turning a blind eye to the repression of independence movements unless forced to do otherwise by public pressure will be a consistent source of embarrassment in coming years; and
(d)calls on the Government to adopt a policy which emphasises the rights of peoples to self-determination, rather than the so-called `right' of states to sovereignty and immutable borders.

(ii)take note of the `Hewson package' so that the road transport industry may plan ahead and have a viable future, because the Labor Government's initiatives will mean fewer trucks and jobs.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the shift in Government policy on East Timor announced on 26 November 1991, and

(ii)the assertion of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) that stronger action against the Indonesian Government was not warranted because there is no evidence that the Dili massacre was ordered from Jakarta;

(c)expresses its conviction that this and numerous other gross violations of human rights on East Timor could have been prevented by Jakarta had it wanted to do so; and
(d)calls on Senator Evans to cease his frantic search for a `fig leaf of credibility' with which to conceal the brutality and illegality of Indonesia's occupation of East Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TAB.TAB: (i)with concern, the failure of the present Government to adequately address the problems of people living in remote and regional Australia,

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that General Business notice of motion No. 486 standing in my name and relating to media ownership be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice standing in Senator Coulter's name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent me moving a motion to provide for consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business Notice of Motion No. 486 standing in my name relating to media ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion, which I believe should be discussed as a matter of urgency by the Senate, is the same motion that was passed, in the terms of a resolution, at well attended public meetings in Melbourne and Sydney. That motion stated:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)expresses support for the resolutions passed at the Fairfax print media public meetings in Melbourne and Sydney addressed by speakers from all political parties; and

(b)urges the Government to take all necessary steps to prevent further concentration of media ownership, and to make sure that planned and future sales of Australian media do not increase foreign ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of regret that honourable senators on both sides of the House do not feel that this matter is urgent enough to be discussed. I believe that many honourable senators actually share the sentiments expressed in the motion. They have signified that by signing petitions, by supporting previous motions and by expressing their feelings about it; although I must say that I have been told by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) that some senators on his side are not as concerned about foreign ownership of Australian media as are the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: It might be useful, in support of my motion that this is indeed an urgent matter that should be discussed by the Senate today, to look at the concentration of media ownership. The metropolitan press is now owned—to the tune of 69.59 per cent—by one person, who is an American, not an Australian, citizen. If we add the Fairfax press ownership of 19.82 per cent to that we finish up with a concentration of 89.41 per cent of the metropolitan press and media being either controlled or owned by people who are not Australian citizens.

With the Sunday newspapers, on the basis of the same formula the final figure would be 98.8 per cent. Perhaps one should consider the regional newspapers. They would reach only 27.31 per cent if we add the Fairfax media organisation share to that currently owned by the Packer press. However, it should be noted that a much higher percentage would be arrived at if the holdings of the O'Reilly group, which currently owns 50 per cent of regional newspapers, were added. In the weeks to come, particularly with the ABT at long last holding an inquiry, attention might well focus on that aspect and on that bid.

In regard to suburban papers we find that 66.1 per cent would be held by those interests. Major magazines would finish up being 86.8 per cent under the control of foreign interests. We might also add to that the fact that there is a 58 per cent potential coverage of television audiences by television stations controlled by Mr Packer.

I believe that we need to pay some attention to the fact that, although we now have an inquiry by the ABT, it does not absolve this Parliament from assessing whether our media should be concentrated to that extent in the hands of two people and, in particular, in the hands of people who are foreign citizens. I draw the attention of the Senate to Mr Packer in particular and to the utter contempt that he has demonstrated for the democratic institutions of this country by his behaviour before the House of Representatives Select Committee on the Print Media. It is fortunate that on that occasion the people of Australia were able to watch Mr Packer's behaviour on television.

There is also the fact that Mr Packer has not shrunk from suing four journalists in Sydney who are members of the Fairfax Free Press Committee—one way of shutting up journalists who express a divergent view. But he has put it on the record in another way as well. He has refused to support the Charter of Editorial Independence. I believe that we in this Parliament have a duty, as representatives of the Australian people, to look at these matters and to make our wishes known. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly indicate the reason why the Government will not be supporting this motion for suspension of the Standing Orders. Senator Spindler first of all referred to the issue of concentration of media ownership and said that it was a matter of urgency that the Parliament and the Senate give consideration to and express its views on the issue of concentration—which, of course, we did on 14 November. I think that the urgency to do so on 27 November is a bit hard to fathom, because a motion on the matter was carried by this chamber on that day.

PARA.TAB: The motion calls for the Senate to support two resolutions which are not outlined and the contents of which I do not know. I have to say that I have never yet endorsed resolutions that other people have carried, however worthy those other people might have been, when I have not known the wording of the resolutions or the full range of their implications. So I certainly do not agree today to making some special arrangement so that we can leap in and endorse resolutions that nobody has seen.

We then go to the question of whether we ought to tag foreign ownership onto this matter of concentration. I would be happy to support the previous motion that was moved. I share the concern that appeared to be unanimous in the chamber because of the way in which the motion was carried that concentration of ownership in the media and in other areas—but we are talking today in the context of the media—is a very important issue in terms of diversity of information sources. I think we would all wish to see ways in which that diversity might be enhanced.

To put the issue of foreign ownership on an equal plane is verging on the xenophobic. There are Australians who own media outlets in other countries without crisis. The United Kingdom has had a very high level of foreign ownership of its media for many years without its newspaper system collapsing, without there being a crisis in its democracy. There is a healthy diversity in the United Kingdom. I do not like the standards of some of its newspapers—some of which were previously owned by Australians and did not exactly run to the highest tone of media. But we are not talking now about whether we agree with the photographs somebody has on page 3 of a newspaper; we are talking about what view we should express as a parliament.

I make two points in conclusion as to why I think it is entirely inappropriate to be charging in and endorsing this motion in this way. Firstly, it is primarily the responsibility of the Parliament to express its views on issues—particularly about ownership of private assets—through legislation. We should set a legislative framework and say, `That is the manner in which this should be dealt with. If you conform with the law, you are entitled to so proceed; if you do not conform with the law, you are not; and, if we do not like the law, we are the people whose obligation it is to change it'. Secondly, we now have the ABT inquiry, announced just yesterday, and I am not sure that it is entirely appropriate for us to be thundering in in this manner this morning.

I think it is a good thing that the Senate previously carried the motion about concentration of ownership because it is not a question of interfering with things that ought properly to be dealt with by legislation. But I think this is not a matter that we ought to be charging in to endorse today. We have the resolution on concentration on the books. I suspect that 75 out of 76 senators, if not 76 out of 76, cannot recall the text of the resolutions we are being called upon to endorse. It is entirely inappropriate that we be called upon to do so. Therefore, I reject the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition will be supporting the suspension of the Standing Orders to allow this debate to proceed. I take up one point that Senator McMullan has mentioned. It does not follow at all that, because he might be unaware of the text of the resolutions passed at various meetings by Friends of Fairfax, he should not allow debate on the subject. He is perfectly right in saying that there is a very heavy onus on those who would wish us to support the resolutions in due course. Indeed, they may already have done themselves a disservice by not spelling out the detail of those resolutions at this stage. Nonetheless, the fact remains that it is proper to have a debate on the very important issue of media concentration, and we welcome that opportunity. I will have a few words to say about that a little later.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear that the Opposition will support the suspension of Standing Orders because this is a very important matter. As Senator McMullan has pointed out, the Senate passed a motion moved by me on 14 November. Nonetheless, events have moved on since then and it is very important, therefore, that we debate this matter this morning.

PARA.TAB: I point out to the Government in this part of the debate that the questions which were posed by Senator McMullan are indeed answered in the second part of the motion. Paragraph (b) of the motion is in the form of the resolutions which were passed at those Melbourne and Sydney meetings. Consequently, he is in possession of the information which would allow him to support the motion before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this motion and I think that the points put forward by Senator McMullan were right. Senator Alston has said, `Why shouldn't we debate a motion even though we do not know the terms of it?'. What concerns me a bit about that is this: the person proposing this motion—a person for whom I have great respect, Senator Spindler—has in the course of his arguments in support of the suspension of the Standing Orders to bring on this debate as a matter of great importance made an attack on Mr Packer. We might or might not like Mr Packer, but it seems to me undesirable for us to go into a debate in which one of the propositions put forward may be that Mr Packer is somebody who is less than desirable.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston knows about proper processes and knows from his long experience what an appropriate approach to things is. I say to him that it is a very bad thing that we come in here of a morning and go into a debate which I agree is very important but which contains in the introduction an attack on a citizen, namely Mr Packer, who, as far as I know, has committed no crime—none which anybody can point to, in any event. He is entitled to nothing but the best of reputations. Nobody has shown him to have in any way disobeyed the law of this country or any other, and for that sort of debate to be brought on without proper notice, without the terms of the debate being expressed precisely so that people's characters are protected—whether they are the most powerful and the richest in the land or whether they are the weakest and the poorest of the land—seems to me to be a most undesirable thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments made by Senator Cooney; I think he is absolutely correct.
—This is on the suspension of Standing Orders.

—This may be on the suspension of Standing Orders, but the big question is whether this Parliament should seek to intervene in what is, to some extent at this stage, a very complicated commercial matter; that is, the getting together of packages by various bidders for the Fairfax empire.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on record here publicly that I am distressed that from time to time recently, and now in this Parliament today, attempts have been made to affect what is a competition between commercial entities bidding for the Fairfax empire. At this stage, Mr Packer is perfectly entitled to put together a proposition, which in no way breaches the law. Neither Mr Packer nor anybody else who may be in the commercial race should be subjected to attacks in this Parliament whilst they are bidders in competition for the Fairfax empire.

I will not make any value judgments about Mr Packer's bid or any other bid. I have my own personal views about those other bids, but I do not think that I am entitled—and nor is any other member of Parliament in this place—to come in here and make statements under parliamentary privilege which would affect the capacity of any of these commercial entities to bid fairly on the open market for the Fairfax empire. Therefore, Senator Cooney is absolutely correct in asking that justice be done to both the rich and the poor in this land in the sense that they should never have to be involved in a parliamentary debate to have their names or their organisations dragged around at the very time when what is said in this place can affect the capacity of those commercial entities—Mr Packer and others included—to make a successful bid for the Fairfax empire or, for that matter, any other empire they may wish to buy.

It is about time we left commercial considerations to commerce, to people who want to put their bids together, provided they are totally within the law. As I understand it, the bids of Mr Packer and the others that I have looked at—those of Mr O'Reilly and the Melbourne based group—are within the law. None of them should be subjected to examination in this place which could affect their capacity to make a genuine bid. Therefore, I oppose any attempt to discuss that issue in this place, unless the issue is of a major national concern so great—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what concentration is.
—I know what concentration is. I was involved, for example, in looking at television equalisation.
—Order! We are discussing the suspension of Standing Orders.

—We are discussing the suspension of Standing Orders, Mr President, but we are discussing the reasons why someone would want to suspend Standing Orders in order to discuss what is purely a commercial situation, and what we say in this place affects that. We have laws about sub judice arrangements before the courts. We also have, I believe, traditions in this place whereby we do not involve ourselves in what are legally competitive bids in the commercial world. Why, for example, is the media so different from the banks, which have as much effect on people's lives as the media?

PARA.TAB: I get back to the point that Senator Cooney made: the suspension of Standing Orders is being sought today—once again in the usual, organised way that we handle ourselves in the Senate—simply to affect the bid by one individual organisation for the Fairfax empire. I totally oppose it on the basis that I do not believe that this will benefit either this Parliament, this debate or, for that matter, the fairness of the whole operation in the bidding for the Fairfax empire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to bring this debate on whether the Standing Orders should be suspended back to the very important subject which is being dealt with, and that is a motion which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)urges the Government to take all necessary steps to prevent further concentration of media ownership, and to make sure that planned and future sales of Australian media do not increase foreign ownership.

It is important to look at the words, `further concentration' because Senator Aulich said that he knows about concentration. It is to the shame of this Government that its media policy has, in the course of its term of office, led to a situation where such a motion before this chamber is so important.

PARA.TAB: What has surrounded this motion has been a specific exercise in the commercial world. We would challenge that framework in which all of that is being dealt with, particularly in the context of foreign ownership. We do not accept that the buying and selling of empires is something which ought to be outside the interests and action of this Parliament. Indeed, these very empires, especially in the media area, have been built up and been able to be built up in large measure by virtue of the media policy of this Government. That policy says `Fling it all out on the marketplace' and rejects any notion that there are very high principles at risk—questions of our own cultural integrity and questions of free and open access to full information via our various media outlets in this country.

In the contribution made by Senator Aulich, he referred to his membership of the committee that examined television equalisation, of which I was also a member. That was really the beginning of the end of the television industry. I note that this motion talks about `media ownership'. Although the issue that is before this country at the moment relates to print media ownership, this motion does not limit that. This motion calls for action in the whole area of media ownership. During the term of office of this Government it has been disgraceful to see the concentration of ownership that has occurred—with, at this stage anyway, the exception of the radio industry. That concentration is what we have to look at in this debate.

It should not be the case that we have a debate such as this only when there is a crisis—and there is a crisis for those among us who are accustomed to reading those fine Australian newspapers which are at risk. As a Melburnian, I point out that it is not only the Melbourne Age but also the Sydney Morning Herald, the Australian Financial Review and so on. We should not have these debates and address these major questions of principle only when there is a crisis. To the extent that there is a crisis, it has been brought on by the policies of this Government with the support of the Opposition. I am really pleased to hear that the Opposition is prepared to support the suspension of Standing Orders on this occasion and I look forward to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That General Business notice of motion No. 486 standing in the name of Senator Spindler, relating to media ownership, be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)expresses support for the resolutions passed at the Fairfax print media public meetings in Melbourne and Sydney addressed by speakers from all political parties; and

(b)urges the Government to take all necessary steps to prevent further concentration of media ownership, and to make sure that planned and future sales of Australian media do not increase foreign ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Senate for giving the opportunity to discuss this topic, which I believe is of national importance. I rebut the suggestion made by Senator Aulich that this is purely a commercial matter. I should have thought that the flow and control of information in a democracy is anything but purely a commercial matter.

PARA.TAB: I would have also thought that this is very much a matter that this chamber should address. On that point, I am rather concerned that the fact that I have put certain factual matters relating to Mr Packer's actions in the past on the public record has been taken as a personal attack on Mr Packer. I have not made, nor do I intend to make, a personal attack on Mr Packer. I have merely drawn to the attention of the Senate certain facts that are already on the public record but which this chamber has not yet considered.

I believe that this chamber has a duty to look at these matters and then to take some action, or at least call upon the Government to take some action. Reference has been made to resolutions on this subject. It has been pointed out that the resolutions passed at public meetings are not before the chamber. I inform the chamber that the substance of those resolutions is contained in subsection (b) of my notice of motion No. 486, which urges the Government to take all necessary steps to prevent further concentration of media ownership and to make sure that planned and future sales of Australian media do not increase foreign ownership. That is the substance of the resolutions and that is what the Australian Democrats would like this Senate to adopt as a resolution.

This is a political, not a commercial, question. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has a discretion, in a case where the equity investment of a foreign owner is 15 per cent or more, of recommending to the Government that this process should be stopped or that it should go ahead in the national interest. I would have thought that the level of foreign ownership of our media, which is a supportive element of our democratic system, is very much the responsibility of this chamber and of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). I believe that we would be charged with negligence as a chamber if we did not address ourselves to that question.

It is quite clear that, when decisions are made about what sort of information goes to our voters and the community via the media and when these media are controlled to the tune of 90 per cent by people who have sworn their allegiance to other nations, one must raise the question: can we really be certain that these interests will always control the flow of information in the interests of this country? It is a legitimate question. Senators on either side of the chamber may come to the view that they do not care if our means of communication are owned by people who have no personal interest as citizens of this country. I strongly disagree. I believe that Australia should control the media process which governs what information and the shape in which this information reaches members of the community.

There is another question to be looked at, and that is whether Mr Packer's 14.9 per cent controlling interest is a controlling interest in the terms of the Broadcasting Act. I would suggest that the wording of section 89KA of the Broadcasting Act 1942 provides that if two or more parties acting together are in a position to exercise control of a television licence or newspaper, each of them should be taken to be in that position.

It is quite clear that, in the case of this bid, Mr Packer and Mr Black are acting in concert. The facts of that bid to that extent are on the public record. I believe that it is incumbent upon this chamber to take note of that. I believe that it is incumbent upon this chamber to take note of the fact that Mr Packer, by the actions that I have outlined, has, in my view, indicated that he intends to be anything but a passive owner, as on some occasions he has claimed. I believe that these matters need to be debated and have a right to be debated in the public arena.

I believe that we must take account of the fact that media concentration of the type we currently have and of the type that would be brought about if this bid proceeds is unacceptable to a civilised, democratic nation. I know of no other nation which is prepared to countenance this degree of media ownership concentration and foreign ownership.

There is one other piece of legislation to which we can turn if we wish to seek some protection, and that is the Trade Practices Act. Unfortunately, we know that section 50 of that Act was amended under Mr Fraser's Government to change the criterion of prohibiting mergers which would lessen competition to the much more lenient test of preventing mergers only if they achieve dominance in the market. That amendment made it possible for Mr Murdoch to take over the Herald and Weekly Times group.

I believe it is time that the Senate and the Government took note of the effects that have flowed from that amendment and returned to the tougher test of prohibiting mergers which lessen competition. This applies even to normal commercial products—to take Senator Aulich's point—but it should apply much more so to what are sometimes termed `sensitive industries', to which the media industry certainly belongs. However, it is unlikely that we would support a differential test. I believe that the test of preventing mergers reaching near monopoly proportions simply through individual steps of lessening competition should be used in this case.

I conclude by saying that the Senate should address the question of the concentration of media ownership; it should address the question of concentration of foreign media ownership; it should be aware of the dangers to our democratic process that such concentration implies; and it should say loudly and clearly that it is unacceptable to the Parliament of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should indicate at the outset that the Opposition will not be supporting the substance of this motion. However, I have made it clear that I thought it was legitimate for the Australian Democrats, and indeed the Senate, to discuss what is clearly a matter of great public concern. We have constantly reiterated our concerns in that area and we recognise the right of persons to come into this chamber and express their concerns.

PARA.TAB: During his speech I think Senator Spindler reflected on Rupert Murdoch being an American citizen. In one sense, that is an example of how easy it is to get carried away with technical notions and end up being in a situation of mindless xenophobia. It is quite clear to us that we ought to judge these things on their merits. We ought to look at whether there is an excess of concentration. That does not necessarily reflect on a person's place of birth or citizenship. Indeed, the home grown product can be as oppressive as he likes or a foreigner can be very hands-off—indeed, in many instances that is more likely to be the case because foreigners will not be involved here on a day to day basis.

I might also say that I think the Government has selective amnesia on this matter. Whilst it does now seem to take a more relaxed attitude as to foreign ownership and adjudge these matters to a certain extent on the merits, I can well remember two years ago when Bond media changed hands and Channel 7 went into receivership largely because the Government was prepared to ram through amendments which reduced the level of ownership of a licence from 49 per cent to 20 per cent. There was no particular need to do that. The rules had been in place since 1981. It was simply a decision taken on the run in the context of current changes.

That is precisely the vice of all these current shenanigans. The rules ought to have been in place long ago. The Government's attitude on foreign ownership ought to have been as it seems to be now and we would not have had this constant preoccupation and speculation about bending the rules to suit the colour of the applicant of the day. I think it is unfortunate in that sense that any proposed changes will be seen in that light and people will quite often read into them motives that may not be accurate.

From our point of view, we do express our concern. Senator Spindler has yet again not gone through the text of the resolutions passed at the public meetings in Melbourne and Sydney in the course of this debate. I suppose they are all so well-known to him that he does not need to. Nonetheless, to conduct a sensible debate in this place, it is highly desirable for people to be specific in what they expect the Senate to be supporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are in paragraph (b) of the motion.

—I thought that either Senator Spindler or Senator Powell was at pains to say that paragraph (a) related to print media and paragraph (b) related to all media. I doubt that the people at the Fairfax meeting were jumping up and down—they may have been—about media at large but, to the extent they were, they were exceeding their own brief.
—It says `print media' under (a), and then under (b) it tells you the substance.
—So those people took it upon themselves to express views on all forms of media ownership, presumably, including magazines.
—It is a relevant factor.

—It is not particularly relevant to a debate about the level of concentration of print media ownership. We certainly support the retention of the cross-media ownership rules. If that is all that Senator Spindler is talking about, I do not think that is at issue. As I read paragraph (b), the Australian Democrats are concerned about increases in foreign ownership in all aspects of the media. That is perfectly consistent with the stance the Democrats have taken over a considerable time.

PARA.TAB: It is a much wider debate than one about print media. It is in that context that we depart most significantly from the thrust of this motion. We do think that there is a sufficient level of discretion under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act to make judgments on the merits. As I have said, there may well be occasions when it is quite desirable to get access to foreign technology, foreign expertise and to those who have a great deal of experience in the industry, in terms of not only technical efficiency but also cultural perspectives. I would not want to rule someone out simply because that person was regarded technically as an American citizen, but I would be very much concerned to make the judgment in this country in terms of any further concentration of ownership. In this respect, that is where the debate ought to start and finish.

We certainly think a case can be argued that further foreign ownership of substantial interests should not be supported unless there is compelling evidence that the outcome of any prohibition of foreign investment would be to increase market concentration and to decrease competition. At the end of the day the debate ought to centre on the extent to which the Trade Practices Commission is able to use its power properly. I would have thought that it would not have any difficulty, in the context of the high levels of concentration that already exist, in saying that any further increase would constitute a dominance, not just a lessening of competition. In that sense, I think the Trade Practices Commission's current powers are adequate to deal with the matter.

We certainly think that it ought to be monitoring developments relating to anticompetitive behaviour in the industry. Successive chairmen have not been backward in expressing their views on the matter. Short of conducting formal inquiries, they have made their views known. We think they ought to continue to do that. At the end of the day we will then have a sensible debate about a level of ownership that is appropriate and to what extent we ought to be tightening up the system. But that sort of debate should not be conducted against the background of bids that are on the table. One of the most fundamental notions of justice is that the rules ought not be changed halfway through a case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just interpreted correctly.

—Fine. We all want to interpret them correctly. Presumably, if they are not, people will take the decisions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to the Federal Court of Australia and to the High Court of Australia in due course. We are in heated agreement, if all Senator Spindler wants is to see justice prevail. It would be quite wrong to start suggesting that somehow the whole process is invalid because it allows levels of foreign ownership that may not be appropriate in some people's judgment.

PARA.TAB: Although we will not be supporting the motion, we acknowledge the right of the Senate to debate these issues. We simply reaffirm our strong adherence to competition policy as being integral to achieving an effectively functioning media in this country. We think there is scope for privatisation and micro-economic reform in many areas of media, as in other areas. Those processes will be facilitated by a strong competition policy. I hope that is the direction that the Senate will take.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty in supporting the motion put forward by Senator Spindler is that it is not quite clear in its intention. That is one of the difficulties—I do not want to go over the previous motion—in bringing on a matter in the way in which this has been. The debate between Senator Alston and Senator Spindler as to exactly what has been put forward illustrates what I am saying. Knowing Senator Spindler, I am sure he has a very clear idea of what he means by the motion he has put forward, and, no doubt, other Australian Democrat senators do as well.

PARA.TAB: If a matter is to be debated in the Senate, I suggest that it be made clear what is being proposed so that the people who are asked to exercise their minds on it and to support it one way or the other know what they are doing. If they do not, the only consequence will probably be that it will be voted down. People will not, and should not, support something that they are not clear about. I was pleased that the debate, conducted by Senator Spindler and Senator Alston, addressed the issues rather than personalities which has perhaps become an unhappy part of this debate.

Senator Spindler spoke about the Trade Practices Act. It seemed to me that he wanted this motion to be dealt with in that context. He realised the difficulty with that as he developed the argument. The Trade Practices Act deals very much with commercial issues. He berated Senator Aulich when Senator Aulich spoke in those terms. I do not think this is a matter that should be looked at within the confines of the Trade Practices Act but, rather, as a separate issue with dimensions other than the commercial ones. The other issue is that the media—the fourth arm of government, as it has been called—has ramifications not only of a commercial nature but also of a social, religious, political and cultural nature within society. It is in that context, rather than being a matter of commercial consideration, that the issue is so important. If it were simply a matter of a commercial deal, it would not raise the passions that it has now.

In my view, the principles that should guide the decision on whether a person or a group should be able to purchase a paper or a piece of the electronic media are as follows: firstly, the media should not be concentrated, and everybody seems to be agreed on that. Secondly, if there is an undue degree of concentration, certainly foreign ownership should be very closely looked at. Thirdly, there should be editorial independence. That cannot be legislated for, but we should have that. In my view, there should also be journalistic independence. Journalists should not be unduly controlled by the editor or the owner. Fourthly, people or bodies that own media of any size should not own other industries of any size. There is a temptation to perhaps not turn as much attention as should be turned to the other industries that are owned, and there is a temptation to promote those industries more than they should be.

Finally, there should not be excessive borrowing overseas. Problems have arisen in the Fairfax press because of excessive borrowing. Those problems could be worsened if all the borrowings were from overseas. If anything were to go wrong, the control of the media outlet would be put into the hands of overseas bankers. So those are the principles that I think ought to guide this issue as to who should own and control the media. The aim of this debate was most noble, but perhaps it has been miscarried in its execution because people do not quite know what they are being asked to vote for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard Senator Alston and now Senator Cooney say that they are not quite sure what they are being asked to vote for. I also heard Senator Spindler tell them that what they are being asked to vote for is contained in part (b) of the motion before us. In any event, it appears that Senator Spindler's word has not been accepted. The speakers there included Gough Whitlam, Malcolm Fraser and me, all former leaders of political parties. At that meeting the following resolution was passed:

SPEECH.PARA: We call on the Federal Government and the Opposition:
To take all necessary steps to prevent further concentration of media ownership.
To make sure that planned and future sales of Australian media do not increase foreign ownership.

The Senate can see that it is quite clear that what is being asked for is a vote on that resolution which is embodied in part (b) of Senator Spindler's motion. As I said, I spoke at that public meeting. There was a subsequent public meeting in Sydney on the following Sunday which passed the same resolution. When I spoke at the meeting in Melbourne I made the commitment that that resolution would come into this Parliament. As a former leader who is still in fact a parliamentarian, I was able to make that commitment. Senator Spindler, in my absence, moved that motion here, and that is why we are debating it.

PARA.TAB: As I said in my contribution to the debate on whether we should suspend the Standing Orders and have this debate in the Senate, it is very important that we address the question on the basis of what the motion actually puts, that is, further concentration of media ownership. To do that we have to acknowledge the high level of concentration of media ownership that we already have in this country. We should be attempting to pass a resolution to divest some of that concentrated ownership, particularly in the print media. It is the case that a particular crisis in print media in this country has brought this question to much more heightened public attention.

I certainly believe that the contributions of Malcolm Fraser and Gough Whitlam, as former politicians and high profile public figures in this country, have been very significant. I have welcomed their contributions because they have come on board together in a quite extraordinary way on a question which is of vital importance. However, it is a question which many of us have been concerned about and have been speaking about for a very long time. I have done so, having had the responsibility for that portfolio since I have been here in 1986.

Therefore I want to briefly put on the record some of the facts. In doing so I will mention the names of some people. I do not want to be portrayed as making any scurrilous attack on those people. I am simply putting facts on the agenda. I will share with the Senate some of the comments of Eric Beecher, a former editor of two major metropolitan daily newspapers. He raised this issue last year in a major article in the Melbourne publication, the Sunday Age. This was at the time when Rupert Murdoch rationalised four of his major metropolitan daily newspapers. On that occasion, Eric Beecher said:

SPEECH.PARA: This week, Australia had 12 daily metropolitan newspapers. Tomorrow it will have 10.
That is courtesy of Rupert Murdoch's rationalisation. Beecher went on to point out that the scoresheet for Australian national dailies is:
Murdoch 15, others (insolvent) 6.

Beecher made the comment in his article that the most interesting thing about that scoresheet is how little interest it arouses in the general public in Australia. That was very much to his dismay. He is actually inaccurate when he goes on to say that:
Other than on the left fringe of the Labor Party, it has never been an issue on the national agenda.

He neglected to note the longstanding concern of the Democrats on this question. Nevertheless, I certainly share his dismay on that issue. However, I welcome the fact that this question is now much more on the public agenda. Beecher went on to pick up a theme that has appeared here in the chamber today—although I think by way of misrepresentation—that when the issue is raised, it is usually raised `in strident anti-Murdoch, anti-foreigner terms which not only debases its importance but detracts from the fundamental issue at stake'. That is the point that Senator Spindler and I have striven to make. When putting items of fact on the record, one has to mention people's names. Nevertheless, those facts cannot be avoided and should not be avoided. I further quote from Beecher who makes the point that:
The reason that newspaper ownership is not an issue in Australia is that most people do not understand the nature of the power that resides in newspapers.
That is a very salient point. We must never underestimate the power of newspapers. I am acknowledging here that the genesis of this debate is the crisis in the newspaper industry.

PARA.TAB: Leaving aside the Fairfax bid, the crisis arises from a situation already in place. Let us extend our view of the Murdoch scoresheet in this case. One organisation in Australia now owns or sponsors seven out of 10 daily metropolitan papers; seven out of nine Sunday metropolitan newspapers; one out of two national daily newspapers; all suburban newspapers in Adelaide and Brisbane; around half the suburban newspapers in Sydney and Melbourne; and most newspaper and magazine printing presses in Australia. That is some concentration. Subsequent to that concentration, is it any wonder that, when the Fairfax empire—small by comparison—is up for grabs, some of us are concerned that we should not allow a further concentration, which is the subject of this motion?

My contribution to this debate has never been necessarily to oppose simply one bid or another bid, but to put facts on the record which demonstrate that should one or other bid be successful certain principles will be breached and certain major issues of concern will have been ignored, such as those of foreign ownership and breadth of ownership. Let us look at some of the statistics which would arise if the Packer-Black bid for the Fairfax operation were successful. Capital city and national newspaper ownership shares would show Murdoch with 61.7 per cent and Packer with 19.8 per cent. The total share held by the two media operators of capital city and national newspaper ownership shares

SPEECH.PARA: would be 81.5 per cent. If this Packer-Black bid were successful, the total concentration of control in metropolitan press would be 89.41 per cent and the Sunday newspaper ownership share would be 98.8 per cent. Also, between the two, regional daily ownership shares would be 27.3 per cent; suburban newspaper ownership shares would be 66.1 per cent; and major magazine ownership shares would be 86.88 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Those statistics in the first instance demonstrate an already existing concentration. We must remember that the Murdoch case, which is the first I quoted, is also foreign owned concentration because it relates to an American citizen. I simply put the second set of statistics on the record to demonstrate the consequences in the broad print media context of a successful Packer-Black bid. It is those facts which we want to bring before the Senate today and which should exercise the minds of honourable senators on both sides when they vote on this motion.

The print media is a medium of extraordinary power; newspapers set up the agenda for discussion on politics, social issues, economics and a wide range of other areas. Perhaps newspapers are now being read by increasingly fewer people because of the impingement of the electronic media, but they are still very much amongst opinion leaders and opinion makers. As Eric Beecher says in the article I have referred to, `Where newspapers lead, TV, radio and the politicians follow'. Of course, the editorial opinions of the newspapers are very influential in our community.

Newspapers are a powerful medium and, as I say, print media concentration is already unacceptable in this country. We should be debating whether or not we divest because let us not forget that divestment is a practice used in media policy and action in the United States—the great home of free enterprise. Why should we flinch from it? We are not even anywhere near that yet. We appear not even able to persuade the Senate to pass a motion, jointly put forward by former leaders of both the old parties in this place, which simply exhorts the Government to take necessary steps through the powers of the Parliament to ensure that there is no further concentration of media ownership and that we are protected against predatory overseas ownership which puts at risk our entire culture and our democracy.

While honourable senators are making up their minds on how they vote on this motion, let us first be clear that what we are not doing here is pillorying any particular individual; what we are doing is challenging a system which has been market driven, and we disagree with the views Senator Aulich outlined on that point. We believe there is a responsibility on the Government and Parliament, on behalf of the Australian nation as a whole, to take action in this area. Indeed, we should have taken action in the past. At this crucial time this Parliament needs to send all the right signals to the proper authorities to stand up for the rights and interests of all Australian people against the commercial empires that have been built up in this deregulated free market system and into the very important and crucial area of media ownership.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Come in Cinderella—the Emergence of Adult and Community Education, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In a few minutes, because of the time available to me, I will seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard. Before Senator Tierney speaks, I will mention one or two matters relating to the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: This matter was referred to the Committee in November of last year. It is the first time in 50 years that we have actually had a comprehensive national view of what is happening to adult and community education; the last one being in 1944. During the inquiry we received more than 300 written submissions and talked to 150 witnesses at public hearings held in all capital cities and in a range of small towns and isolated communities across the nation.

As I indicated in the foreword of the report, we actually began the hearings in Merredin, which is a small town in the middle of the wheat fields halfway between Kalgoorlie and Perth. Mr Acting Deputy President nods his head; he would be very familiar with that town. There would be a few Liberal voters there and many Australian Labor Party voters.

It was interesting that we started the hearings in that town. We were given an indication of the types of services that were being provided by the adult and community education providers throughout this nation. We visited neighbourhood houses, farms, colleges and prisons. We looked at the incredible variety of adult and community education services that are being provided throughout this country.

The speech that I will incorporate summarises the findings of the report. The report is unanimous. Although the report deals with a very important and wide ranging subject, every member of the Committee has agreed on its recommendations and the format. I also thank the Committee staff—Brenton Holmes, Mary Lindsay, Rosemary Brissenden, and Ros Franklin, who was the executive assistant for some time—for the work that they did on this report. It was an enormous amount of work in terms of the number of threads that had to be drawn together. It provides a pen picture of how adult and community education is provided in every State. That, in itself, is a very complicated exercise.

The report then looks at all of those other adult and community education providers, ranging from those who provide prison education to those who are running neighbourhood houses. If honourable senators are under the impression, as are many Australians, that adult and community education is about hobbies and recreation, with a few night classes here and there, they should look very closely at some of the figures that we provide in this report. For example, at some time in their lives, six out of 10 Australians will be involved in adult and community education; 1.7 million people went through neighbourhood houses in the last year or so; 300,000 people went through community colleges in New South Wales.

There has been a veritable explosion of educational demand in this country over the last three or four years. The adult and community education providers have had to deal with that explosion. As we show in our report, the formal education system has been quite unable to cope with that demand. For example, 30,000 university students will not find places in the formal university system next year; about 100,000 people will not find places in the formal TAFE system next year. They have to go somewhere.

With respect to the migrant population, for example, we indicated that 360,000 migrants who were born overseas have great difficulty in speaking English; 170,000 of them are already in the work force. Yet our migrant education program deals only with those people who have arrived in the last five years. So the majority of those who are already in the work force will not be able to enjoy the advantages of learning English in a formal situation. The adult and community education providers will have to go out and reach those target groups. That illustrates some of the issues that are raised in this report.

Without going into detail, this report will be in as much demand as the Committee's report on priorities and reform in higher education which, believe it or not, actually sold out in government bookshops. Perhaps the response of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) helped that. I believe that Come in Cinderella will be just as popular because it is the first report since 1944 to cover the whole of this area on a nationwide basis. Its recommendations are a fair summation of the submissions given to us by groups around the country. It gives me great pleasure to table the report Come in Cinderella.
