SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I present the Report of the Senate Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled "Come in Cinderella—the emergence of Adult and Community Education."

This matter was referred to the Committee in November of last year, the first time in fifty years that adult and community education has been the subject of a national inquiry. Our findings have justified the Senate's interest in the subject. Since we began our Inquiry my Committee has received more than 300 written submissions and talked to 150 witnesses at public hearings held in all capital cities and in a range of small towns and isolated communities across the country.

Until we began our investigation into adult and community education we had little idea either of the scope of the sector or of the significance of its contribution to the educational, economic and social well being of the nation and to individual participants. Committee members have been both surprised and impressed by the efforts of tutors, coordinators and local management committees all over the country who, with minimal resources and little official recognition or support, have successfully reached out to the many people in our community whom the `formal' sectors of education—schools, TAFE and the tertiary sector—have been unable to assist.

Adult and community education has already touched the lives of six out of ten adult Australians and it is growing faster than any other area of education. It operates throughout the length and breadth of the country—from the central business districts of our capital cities to isolated mining settlements; amongst urban migrant communities and in remote Aboriginal groups. Diversity is the key to its success. It runs courses on every conceivable subject at all levels from primary school to post doctoral. Its approaches are equally varied, ranging from formal, highly structured courses to discussions over a cup of tea. The subjects taught and the approaches adopted are, like everything else in adult and community education, a response to the varied needs of the students. This responsiveness is another key to the sector's success.

People unfamiliar with its operations have tended to devalue the contribution of the sector, or belittle its efforts. The Committee hopes, through this Report, to raise the profile of the sector by informing the public in general and policy makers in particular of the valuable work which it is undertaking.

A number of recent and future developments are likely to increase demands upon the sector. In the workplace these include award restructuring, increased participation of women in the workforce and the introduction of the Training Guarantee Act. More generally, social and demographic changes such as the movement into the community of people with disabilities and the general ageing of the population are likely to have an effect both upon the demand for education and upon the type of education required.

The adult and community education sector is already responding to these challenges. It is providing basic literacy and numeracy to workers through courses conducted in the workplace, in TAFE classes or in community settings and private homes. It is assisting professional and other members of the workforce to upgrade their skills. It is helping those who would like to join the workforce by increasing their confidence—an intangible but significant benefit which this sector has been particularly successful in achieving—and providing for many people the first step towards further study or paid employment.

Its community based, non threatening settings are especially valuable in assisting groups likely to be intimidated by large institutions and formal approaches, such as people with disabilities needing to acquire basic living skills and migrants needing to learn English. The dramatic growth in enrolments in those fourth sector organisations catering to the needs of older people such as the Universities of the Third Age and the Schools for Seniors are sufficient testimony to the sector's ability to respond to demands as they emerge.

Our Report points out that the impressive achievements of the sector have taken place despite its minimal resources, variable levels of official recognition and a lack of overall policy direction. It shows, for example, that government financial support to the sector has actually decreased in some States despite the steady growth in enrolments and the increasing demands upon the sector. It is the only sector of education in which participants are expected to bear most of the costs, and in which the majority of educators and administrators are volunteers. It is grossly inefficient for governments to ignore or neglect the sector's remarkable education and training capacity, particularly as relatively small additions of guaranteed funding to the sector will reap significant additional benefits in terms of overall levels of skills formation, to say nothing of the abundant personal and community benefits.

The Committee concluded that the sector will be unable to maintain its extraordinary performance, let alone increase it, without greater administrative, financial and policy support, the absence of which now threaten the viability of the whole operation. To afford the sector the recognition which it has long been denied, and to avert the very real threat of its disintegration the Committee has recommended the immediate establishment of a high level Working Party charged with responsibility for developing national policy and funding guidelines for the sector.

The Committee also recommends that the Commonwealth's views on policy and funding should be developed and refined by an Advisory Committee consisting of representatives of all major provider types and reporting to the Minister
through the National Board on Employment, Education and Training and that implementation of Commonwealth policy should be the responsibility of a designated office within DEET.

The most important and most urgent task for the Working Party will be the development of a national policy on adult and community education. The need for such a policy, and for greater recognition, was stressed repeatedly to the Committee throughout its Inquiry. Possible components of such a policy were also widely discussed. The Committee has formed the view that there is broad agreement in the sector on the essential elements of a national policy. These are encapsulated in the Recommendations.

Mr President, adult and community education is a large and complex topic and my Committee Report covers a wider range of issues than it has been possible to address here today. The Committee expects this Report to play an important part in alerting policy makers to the need for urgent action. It is time for adult and community education to emerge from its Cinderella status and to assume its rightful place alongside the formal education sectors.

I commend the Report and its Recommendations to the Senate, to education policy makers and advisers in the Commonwealth and State Governments and to all those involved in adult and community education, whether as administrators, tutors or students.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been presented with a report from the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Come in Cinderella—the Emergence of Adult and Community Education. The title is very apt because adult and community education has been largely ignored by government and other education policy makers. While being ignored, however, the sector has gone quietly about its business, making an immeasurable contribution to our society—educationally, economically and socially.

PARA.TAB: It has been stated by Senator Aulich that it is remarkable that this is the first time in 50 years that any investigation has been made of this vibrant but largely forgotten sector in our education system. This review is long overdue. What we have discovered is a versatile, diverse and responsive area of education that is growing faster than any other area. That has been done with almost no government support, minimal resources and no official recognition. It is a tribute to the dedication and efficiency of the many people involved in adult and community education who have reached out to those people so desperately in need of these programs.

It is the fact that the sector is very responsive to the diverse range of demands from the community that has made it so successful and has led to such dramatic growth over recent years. Sixty per cent of Australians have participated in adult and community education. In New South Wales in the last 10 years the participation rate has trebled from 100,000 a year to 300,000 a year; in Queensland the demand has increased by almost 10 per cent each year for the last 15 years. These extraordinary demands will continue in the future with more and more people wishing to enter the work force who were never able to do so previously. As our economy undergoes structural redevelopment, it creates new need for retraining of the work force.

The benefits that are currently being derived from this sector are social and economic in nature. Job related adult education courses often lead to increased income for the individuals and, therefore, to more government revenue. Also, one-third of unemployed people who are participating in adult education will subsequently gain employment. In addition, social benefits occur through increased confidence that individuals develop through adult education. This fourth sector of our education system is catering specifically for the needs of the disadvantaged in our society who tend to be ignored, if not shunned, by the mainstream education system; it encompasses teaching non-English speaking migrants to adopt English; it is helping the disabled to learn life skills; it is helping women who wish to re-enter the work force to retrain; and it is helping the unskilled worker regain a place in the work force. This assistance to adult and community education is enabling the disadvantaged to overcome specific obstacles and to take their rightful place in society, making valuable contributions that would otherwise have been lost.

In our formal education system that role has largely been undertaken by the TAFE system. This sector is grossly overburdened with excessive numbers and is not capable of meeting the demands made on it. Similarly, the higher education sector is not able to cope with community demands for its educational services. In 1992 there will be at least 140,000 students denied access to TAFE and probably around 30,000 denied access to university places. It is reasonable to expect that many of these people will try to find some sort of educational opportunity in the adult and community education sector. It is telling that, in looking at putting extra billions into the formal education system, no thought has been given to extra funding for the diverse, efficient and largely user-pays adult and community education sector. This fourth sector has a comprehensive range of providers. They should be assisted to respond to the dramatically increased demand being placed upon them as the formal education system groans under the weight of numbers.

Disparity in funding gives an insight into how productive this sector is and how much potential it has. Yet, at the same time, we see that it needs urgent help from the Commonwealth. In New South Wales, for the financial year 1990-91, TAFE got 200 times the funding of the adult and community education sector for less than double the number of students. Adult and community education is 90 per cent self-funding while other sectors are overwhelmingly funded by government. In 1991 the Commonwealth spent $209m on TAFE infrastructure while adult and community education received no funding at all.

Despite this lack of funding, it is expected that adult and community education will act as a safety net for those people in need of education, especially workplace training, that are not assisted by the TAFE system at present. Many adult education agencies other than TAFE have had substantial experience in such matters. Large metropolitan based providers such as the Workers Education Association and the Council of Adult Education have developed considerable expertise and won substantial contracts from industry for the design and implementation of training programs. Rural adult education providers are often the key resource for training for local enterprises. Such a role for the sector should be recognised and supported by government keen to see the enhancement of training commitment.

An excellent example of this is the Council of Adult Education's involvement with the development of the clerks training model project, which links the training system with workplace and industry needs. The primary task has been the identification and description of clerical skills, the development of competence statements related to those skills and the establishment of assessment systems. The result is that clerical workers now have a career path through identified levels of competency. Similar examples of the sector's close links with industry include the Victorian Council of Adult Education's involvement in basic education settings ranging from heavy industry to clothing and service industries. Unions and management were involved in all aspects of developing and implementing these policies and all acknowledged the benefits that accrued from these programs.

These examples, found among others in the Senate Committee report, show that adult education providers generally have the experience, and importantly the flexibility, to devise programs in the workplace relevant to the needs of workers. Community providers are well placed to understand the operations, needs and aspirations of local industries and their employees. It is therefore imperative that policy makers and funding agencies do not overlook the adult and community education sector as a source of developing workplace training expertise.

The amazing success of this sector has also been reflected in the way in which it deals with other disadvantaged people in our community who desperately need the education services that the fourth sector alone seems able to provide. The single most important program targeted to migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds is the adult migrant English program—or AMEP—which has been operating since 1947. The program is designed to assist recent migrants to acquire sufficient English to obtain appropriate employment or access to mainstream education and training and to function effectively within society. However, this is due to suffer large funding cuts. It is a great pity that it is not being funded at a sufficient level at this time.

During our inquiry in Adelaide a Turkish lady came before us who was a qualified accountant in Turkey; she had no English skills. When she came out here she received priority for an English program, but because of lack of funds she was entitled to only 300 hours of training, enough to get a person up to conversational English level. To get to a normal standard of English she would have needed another 300 hours. To become a functioning accountant she would have needed a further 300 hours. However, this was not available. Therefore, instead of the lady becoming a productive member of our society and being an accountant, she went on to social welfare. Instead of being a benefit to our country economically, she became an economic drain on the country. It would have been so much more cost effective to spend the money to increase her language skills so that she could contribute to society and take her proper place in our economy.

Many migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds are in a similar position. They do not receive training from the formal sector and are turning more and more to adult and community education to provide for their needs. Many prefer this sort of education; they prefer to be in neighbourhood houses and similar community settings which they consider more convenient and less intimidating than the more formal approach of the AMEP classes. In rural areas where AMEP has had a low profile, community providers were in any case the only accessible source of education for migrants who lacked the language skills to attend TAFE courses. Their numbers are likely to increase substantially without any commensurate increase in government funding to the adult and community education sector, despite the fact that in effect it will be undertaking some of the work previously done through AMEP.

Among those who are, or could be, even greater beneficiaries of adult and community education are people with disabilities. The proportion of Australians suffering from a disability is high and is expected to reach 24 per cent by the end of the century. People with disabilities face the common problem of gaining access to the established sectors of education. These constraints, thankfully, do not apply to the same extent to those in the fourth sector, enabling a significant contribution to be made to their continuing education. Encouragement and resourcing of the sector, therefore, would be consistent with the desire to actively promote integration of people with disabilities into the community. But often the resources are just not available on a long term basis.

During a visit by the Committee to the Hunter we saw a group of psychiatric patients going through a basic literacy course. The program obviously was of great benefit to the patients and they were making considerable progress. However, it was a pilot program and future funding was in doubt. The health department saw it as the responsibility of the education department, and education saw it as the responsibility of the health department. Such courses fill a real need. Adult and community education has many programs that do not fit into traditional funding mechanisms. This sector tends to be demand driven and client centred and is therefore better able to respond to the needs of individual participants than the formal education system. It is flexible enough, for example, to increase the time allowed for mastery of a particular skill if this will facilitate its attainment by slow learners.

These specific examples show why this forgotten sector is important to the development and future of Australia. Yet the sector is still ignored in any major reviews into education, and Australia is the only OECD country without a national policy on adult education. This report draws attention to the lack of funding to the sector, particularly in relation to the other more conventional sectors of education which are increasingly overburdened and expect the fourth sector to take up the slack.

With these considerations in mind, the Committee made several recommendations. An aspect that came across very clearly from almost all submissions to the Committee was the need for a national policy. Without the necessary support from the Commonwealth, the fourth sector is in great danger of disintegration. Recognition and immediate action are necessary in developing a national policy to act as a directional and cohesive force in this area of education. To this end the Committee has recommended that a working party be established to formulate this policy. This development will need great input from the adult and community educators so that the needs of users and the special flexibility and responsiveness of the sector is maintained and so that it does not become fettered with bureaucracy and government directives.

Official recognition at the Federal level will lead to increased funding and the adult and community education sector will be better equipped to meet the challenges that lie ahead, to expand and to contribute even further towards a more productive, educated and confident Australia. I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to address a few brief remarks to the tabling of the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on the emergence of adult and community education. The compilation of this report is the first I have been able to observe from start to finish since I entered this Parliament. The very process of information gathering which has resulted in this report has been important because, as has been previously said, this sector of education is very different from the other education sectors which are given much more formal recognition and which have attached to them a greater degree of government and bureaucratic control.

PARA.TAB: Elements of this sector are often unable to communicate with each other. They do not often have the opportunity to meet, to share information and to provide information to the Government or its representatives. In the course of the public hearings that were conducted in the process of compiling the report, information sharing was taking place. I suppose that it could be argued that community education was taking place at those public hearings. I suggest that there was certainly a considerable amount of education of Committee members taking place.

On a number of occasions, witnesses at our hearings presented information which we would have been unable to glean in any other forum. Some 305 submissions on this particular topic were presented to the Committee. A considerable number of those 305 submissions were not just from individuals but from groups representing considerable numbers of people from other interest groups. It really was a very wide net that was cast in order to gather information to present to the Committee.

I think the Chairman was hinting that he would like to see the report become another best-seller for the Committee. There was some reaction to that suggestion. I think that the report does deserve to enter the best-seller stakes because it is unique in the field of adult and community education. In the past, it has been very difficult for researchers to describe fully the extent of the provision of adult and community education. The Committee used the phrase `to map the provision of adult and community education'. The Committee found that that mapping process was very expensive and that it has not been successfully achieved in this field. The reasons for this failure are soon evident and very obvious. For instance, we have the geographical limitations of this country. Also, what is included in the definition of adult and community education is very wide. In fact, the definition gives some trouble to people who are trying to map what is provided.

In that process we very soon realised that there was a unique opportunity available to the Senate Committee because of the resources that are provided to committees in general. I think that is something that ought to be noted. I think that the resources which are available to a committee—to investigate, to travel, to invite submissions and to facilitate the provision of information—are unique. They have resulted in a description of what is provided which is not easily obtainable in any other way. That would justify this report becoming a best-seller because those people who are interested in adult and community education would have difficulty in finding a similar compilation of information to that presented in the report.

The report, as well as being comprehensive, is also a little provocative—as it should be; as it deserves to be; and as the providers of adult and community education would want it to be. They would expect a description of their sector of education to provoke the decision makers into recognising the tremendous benefits provided to Australia by this sector. They would also expect it to provoke the decision makers into not only recognising the sector but also increasing the provision of government resources to this sector. This report does that. The Chairman said on our behalf at most of the hearings that he would like—we supported him in this request; I know that I speak on behalf of my colleagues who sat on the Committee—those people who made submissions to the Committee to regard the report as an opportunity to engage in further debate, to make comments and to follow the report through. The report explores recent developments which are likely to increase demands on the adult and community education sector. Although those developments may be self-evident to some people, the report at least spells out the reasons why adult and community education will be expanding in the near future. The report teases out developments such as workplace restructuring and the need for regular upgrading of workers' skills which will increase the demands on this sector. Senator Tierney mentioned the dramatic changes occurring in the status of people with disabilities in the community. There is an increase in the number of people who are moving from institutions into the community. Such a move will increase the demand for the provision of courses and support from the adult and community education sector.

There are also likely to be increased demands on this sector as a result of changes in community attitudes to training as labour market reforms become increasingly evident—especially with the labour market itself becoming competitive. Also, an increasing number of elderly people in our community will require intellectual stimulation, company and new interests. These are all vital changes in the community that will bring about an increased demand for the provision of services within the adult and community education sector.

The report makes recommendations which are connected with those changes. That recommendation may seem a little glib or superficial, but the Committee did not make that recommendation in that manner. To be able to distil that requirement from the 305 submissions and those who presented themselves as witnesses was not a difficult task because it was a consistent and loudly stated recommendation from those who contributed. It goes on to recommend that the Commonwealth:

TALK.START.PARA: —From our point of view, very little needs to be said about the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) and related Bills, largely because my colleague Warwick Smith in the other place has given a very extensive analysis of the implications of the Bills and our intention to support them.

PARA.TAB: Reforms in this area are long overdue, particularly in radio. As in many areas of micro-economic reform, the Government has been moving slowly and this is no exception. The measures for the faster delivery of new FM commercial and supplementary radio services to regional listeners under the regional radio program are to be welcomed. The replacement of the current establishment in AM-FM conversion fees with an FM access fee to be paid by all commercial and supplementary non-metropolitan radio licensees before they commence service on the FM band is an improvement.

The decision to permit a supplementary radio licence to serve an area smaller than that served by the related commercial radio licences would also seem to be a step in the right direction. Although one can argue that there is no good reason why an existing AM operator should not be entitled to automatically apply for an FM licence, one would hope that, as part of the evolution, that will be seriously addressed in due course.

There are a number of matters of some significance, although they do not warrant amendments, let alone opposition. One is the watering down of the term `commercial viability' which has long been an article of faith in the radio industry. Those of us who have been close to it on occasions have always received representations from FARB and others about how terribly important that concept is.

Whilst one can understand their concern, if one genuinely wants to encourage new players into the market by adhering to a strict definition of commercial viability in requiring the ABT to take it into account each time a licence is granted, one is effectively putting in place an important barrier to entry. Therefore, we welcome the winding back of that concept. It probably could go further and, as Mr Smith pointed out, there are a number of areas that also warrant overhaul in conjunction with the change in emphasis on commercial viability.

If we are to go much more towards a deregulated industry, and we think that now is an appropriate time to do that, we need to look at some of these other concepts which can clog up the system inordinately. I recall some of those licence hearings were sometimes two and three years out-of-date because of the backlog. In most instances they were pro-forma exercises but they required the applicants to put in an enormous amount of preparation on the off-chance that someone might want to come along and object.

So there is, I am sure, scope for even more deregulation and freeing up of the system. At the end of the day, this is a mature industry and one in which most of the major players are professionals. Those who are not have probably gone broke by now. There are some very experienced and capable people; they are the ones who will survive under any regime and they are the ones in many respects who have the most to gain from a more deregulated approach in this area.

So we welcome the thrust of these changes. In many respects they will make life a lot easier and, hopefully, cheaper in compliance costs for the bulk of the industry. But there are still some unnecessary restrictions, for example, on the level of Australian music content and certainly the labour market limitations that riddle this and most other areas at present because this Government somehow regards labour market deregulation as not part and parcel of micro-economic reform. We all understand why that is; it will pay the penalty in due course. But if those areas can be properly addressed and we can free up the system then we are well on the way to getting a more viable and enduring radio industry. For those reasons we support the package of Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to speak virtually as briefly on the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill as I did on the previous piece of legislation. I say that for the information of the Opposition Whip. What I am about to say will be truncated a great deal by the Government's foreshadowed action in putting forward a significant amendment to this Bill subsequent to its passage through the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill now before the Senate, which is the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1991, is one of the most interesting Bills we have had before the Parliament for quite a while, and it is one that I have enjoyed spending some time examining. The Bill seeks to amend the parent Act of 1959. As Senator Powell just said, this Bill has been very heavily amended by the Government since its presentation to the House of Representatives when the Opposition voted against it.

PARA.TAB: With the greatest respect to the Government, this Bill represents some very muddled thinking. It could well be argued that the Bill ought to be defeated and that we will not be any worse off. If it was defeated, the Government could take time to think its position through and come up with something that is more appropriate for the Australian travelling public.

What the Government is trying to do is not clear. I think I know what it is trying to get at, but one simply could not be certain, given the changes we have had to this Bill. If we pass this Bill, not only will some of the problems we presently have still exist but also we will create a number of new ones, which I will refer to later in my address. As I said a few minutes ago, the best thing for the Parliament and the country would be if the Bill was withdrawn and thought through properly.

The Government is pushing ahead with the Bill as a matter of urgency and with an air of haste which is quite clear when you talk to the Government about it. The reason for the Government's panic is that it is arguing that, if the Bill does not go through, the United States is likely to sign Montreal Amendment Protocols Nos 3 and 4 and Australian carriers would then be exposed to unlimited liability with respect to the United States. The Government is saying that an Australian airline could be taken to court and there would be no upper limit on the liability that it would bear towards passengers or cargo in the event of injury or death to those passengers.

I want to make two points about the proposition that there is urgency. One is an opinion and the other is fact. The Government says that it is acting on advice from the Australian foreign affairs department in Washington that the United States is very close to signing Montreal Protocols Nos 3 and 4 in the Congress. I have a very great respect for the Australian foreign affairs officers in Washington and for their professional judgment. I probably know the people involved and know them quite well. But the advice I am getting is to the contrary. My advice is that the United States will not in the near future, and probably never will, sign the Montreal agreements. After all, it has had nearly 16 years to do so. The matter is simply bogged down in the Congress.

The United States has lifted the liability of carriers from the present Warsaw-Hague conventions up to a minimum of $75,000 for carriers operating into and out of the United States. But whether the United States signs is a matter of opinion and it is something we will not resolve here this morning.

The second point is a matter of fact. If the United States Congress does sign the Montreal Amendment Protocols or becomes a signatory to that convention, it follows that the United States will have to give a six-month period before it moves away from the existing protocols. In other words, if the United States goes ahead with MAP Nos 3 and 4 and its supplemental compensation plan and decides to denounce the existing Warsaw conventions, there will be six months for the Australian Government to come in with legislation to cover Australian carriers for any anomaly that might arise.

Another fact in relation to that matter also has to be considered: for Montreal Protocols Nos. 3 and 4 to take effect there have to be 30 signatories. I am told that at the moment only 19 countries have signed up. If the Americans sign, that makes only 20 countries—or 21 including Australia. It is a long way short of the threshold required to pass the convention into law.

I would like to put what we are talking about into perspective. We are talking about passengers and cargo that are carried by an airline and the responsibility that the airline bears for compensation in the event of death or injury to those passengers or to loss or damage of that cargo. The first protocol that was introduced to cover this was the Warsaw Convention of 1929 when aviation, as honourable senators would recall, was very much in its infancy. It was several magnitudes less in volume, both with respect to passengers and freight, to that which it is today. An interesting sideline to that is that the first Warsaw Convention was introduced in 1929 as an interim measure, yet here we are nearly 61 years later and one of those protocols is still in place. In 1955 it was amended with the Hague-Warsaw amendments. They virtually doubled the liability that the carriers bore in the event of an accident.

Today about 130 states are signatories to the either the original Warsaw Convention or the Warsaw Convention as modified by the Hague Protocol. Those conventions have some very important characteristics, and I would like to mention a couple of them. First of all, there is the principle of strict liability. Strict liability means that the carrier has an obligation to pay in the event of a claim, without the claimant having to go through all the business of taking out a court action against the airline. We can imagine the great cost involved to a person who is fighting an airline, which has very much greater funds than a private citizen. Of course, when there is an argument about an operational matter, the airline can call on enormous technical resources as compared to those available to a private individual. That is the strict liability. To get an action against a company, someone can claim without having to go through a great court procedure.

The second thing is that the Warsaw Convention provides what is known as a breakable liability. In other words, if someone does feel that there has been gross negligence by the carrier, that person can resort to legal action and the liability limit, therefore, is not fixed. If, say, the limit is set at $100,000 in the event of a loss of life, and if a person can show that the reason for the accident was gross negligence on behalf of the airline, that person can go to court and that $100,000 is not the upper limit to compensation.

The third great thing about the present conventions is that signatories—by that I mean airlines—can set higher limits than are provided as a minimum. If the airlines feel that their cover is not adequate, is not reasonable with respect to current costs, they can lift them.

Originally these liabilities were defined in terms of gold. The great change that the Government has made in the amending legislation that is now before us is to resolve the great uncertainty that has bedevilled these conventions since 1929 as to the level of compensation the airlines had to meet. Originally, the levels were defined in terms of gold and the gold standard. Since gold now operates in a free market and the price of gold fluctuates, the industry is devoid of a realistic benchmark. One of the difficulties with the existing legislation has been the problem of equating a value under standards which are no longer applicable.

That has been resolved by the Government agreeing to delete a series of clauses in the Bill that it presented in the House of Representatives, setting values for compensation and now using exclusively the International Monetary Fund special drawing rights provisions. The special drawing right is an arbitrary unit based on five international currencies—a basket of currencies—which in itself is a floating value, but at least it provides some benchmark for setting compensation limits.

In 1971, seeing shortcomings that principally arose from the gold standard and setting a value on liability, there was a conference which led to the Additional Protocol No. 3 of Montreal, which I referred to earlier, which basically relates to passengers, and the Montreal Protocol No. 4 which basically relates to cargo. Those new conventions were placed on the table in 1975. As I said earlier, since 1975 so far only 19 countries have signed up as signatories to them. In the interim, most airlines have raised their limits above the original limits of the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol. Under those conventions the facility exists for airlines unilaterally to raise their limits.

Still, 30 per cent of international carriers coming into and leaving Australia are operating under the original Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol. The Government is proposing here that we sign the Montreal Convention. There are some difficulties with that, in my opinion. The first problem is that it does set an unbreakable limit. In other words, in the case of gross negligence there is no way that a claimant on the airlines can exceed the limit of 100,000 SRD units which is the liability of the carrier who is a signatory to the Montreal Convention. There is no opportunity for the carriers, unilaterally, to lift their limit if they feel that it is inadequate. Very clearly, the limit set at the present time of 100,000 SRD units is far too low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a workplace agreement at Rheem Australia that is based on wage increases in return for improvements in productivity? It is a good example of the Government's policy to encourage direct bargaining in the workplace through the relevant unions and management. The negotiations have been conducted in a very positive way. It is a good example of cooperation replacing conflict in the Australian workplace.

PARA.TAB: The negotiations have been aimed at making this company internationally more competitive. It is a win-win outcome for both the employees and the company. The company is looking at the prospect of having increased productivity and profits; and, of course, the employees are looking at improved wages as a consequence of these negotiations and improved career paths for themselves in the future.

Rheem employs about 360 workers. Both the workers and management have set their sights on matching and beating the productivity levels of their US counterpart. The company has already achieved the first target of 2.1 labour hours for each water heater, down from 2.65 hours. Because of this achievement, workers will receive a wage rise of $15 per week. Further wage increases are linked to the achievement of further reductions in hours taken to produce each water heater.

Therefore, as a consequence of this workplace agreement, we have seen increased productivity and a reduction in unit labour costs, achieved without the trade-off of any award conditions at all. We have seen the beginnings of an important cultural change in this workplace, for which both management and unions should be congratulated. Rheem Australia in the 1970s and in the early 1980s had a history of turbulent and dispute ridden industrial relations. That seems now to have changed. Because of the stability engendered in the industrial relations climate by the accord between the Government and the ACTU, the reforms that we have made to industrial relations, and the promotion by the Government of benchmarking for world best practice, we now see the possibility of the emergence of a new cultural shift in the Australian workplace. It ought to be, as Senator Aulich has drawn attention to in the second part of his question, contrasted with the divisive nature of industrial relations in this country in the Fraser years. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the annual report of the Affirmative Action Agency for 1990-91. Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether this report gives any indication of employers growing more aware of their legal obligation to improve employment opportunities for women?

—Yes, it does. The Affirmative Action Agency's report was tabled in the Senate yesterday. The Affirmative Action Agency is set up under the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment for Women) Act 1986. It is an important Act of the Parliament. It aims to reduce inbuilt discrimination that women suffer in the workplace as a matter of course. It requires medium to large employers to examine their business practices to see that merit, not gender, is the basis for employment and promotion. The Act works by declaring those as the goals for employers and promotes them through the Agency as good employment standards. It also requires companies to file an annual report to show what they are doing about achieving those standards.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, at about the time of the tabling of the report, I released the triple A rating report put out by the Affirmative Action Agency. This is a report of 24 Australian companies which apply affirmative action in a way which can be regarded as a model for other companies in Australia. They see affirmative action as a means of introducing world best practice in standard employment conditions. All of those companies—many of them well-known and household names in Australia—sing the praises of policies that aim at ensuring that there is merit based advancement and recruitment in employment.

This year the Affirmative Action Agency's report covered some 2,400 Australian companies. There was a 98 per cent return by companies covered in the report. That is a record for the Agency. I congratulate those employers who have complied, and the Agency. It means that there is still a way to go. We now have medium to large employers in Australia focusing on the issue. A bit more work needs to be done, in collaboration with them, to make some more progress in removing structural discrimination in the workplace.

Forty-four companies were named in the report as not complying with the report. Seventeen of those companies have not complied for the second year in a row. They are, as I have said, the bad guys. One company, Suttons Investments Pty Ltd in New South Wales, had not complied over the last three years. Towards the end of last year it complied after the report was tabled. It complied again this year. I congratulate that company, which tried to thumb its nose at the Act in its initial stages. It has finally seen that it made a mistake and is bringing its employment practices into compliance.

I commend the report of the Affirmative Action Agency as a good example of this Government working with employers in Australia to uphold reasonable employment standards in the workplace and to remove the stigma of discrimination, particularly against women.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Sales Tax Exemptions on Transport Costs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: does he support the statement by Treasurer Kerin in his confidential letter yesterday to the Caucus Economic and Industrial Relations Committee outlining the desirability of withdrawing sales tax exemptions that presently exist for rail, sea and air transport?

—It is not my habit to comment on private mail. But if Senator Short likes to do what his colleague Senator Hill did and table the letter, I will have a look at it and give him a comment in due course.
—I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as a supplementary question I ask the Minister: what would be the cost impact to Australian business, particularly exporters and import competing producers, of this proposed addition of a non-refundable sales tax on transport costs?

—It would be a significant increase in the cost to business.
—No, no. Senator Short asked me about removing these imposts.
—Failing to do so.

—All right. Let us get it clear. If we removed these imposts it would be a benefit to business and a significant cost to revenue, I suspect. That is in terms of the wholesale sales tax. I will try to get Senator Short an answer on that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree that the change in price levels which would occur as a result of the introduction of a goods and services tax would be the key determinant of whether proposed compensation arrangements are fair? Secondly, the Minister confirmed in answer to a previous question that Treasury will be analysing some aspects of the GST package. Will Treasury specifically be analysing the claim that the GST package, if implemented, would have only a 4.7 per cent effect on the consumer price index?
—It will be 4.4 per cent.
—Whose claim is it? Finally, will the Minister give a commitment that the results of any Treasury analysis will be made available to the public, irrespective of what the results are?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Mr President, I seek your advice. In a matter such as this where the Democrat Senator is asking the detail and explanation of a proposal of the Opposition, should not such a question be directed to the Leader of the Opposition, who knows what he is talking about in the estimation of these matters, and not addressed to the Government which knows nothing about how those matters were determined? Should the Democrats not be directing their questions to the Opposition?
—Order! There is no point of order. The question was in order because it asked for factual information from the Leader of the Government. I call Senator Button.

—In general terms, whether it be here or in other countries, when a general goods and services tax has been introduced, the compensation package has related to the burden imposed on ordinary members of the community by the introduction of that tax. The compensation has been in respect of that additional burden. I just make the point that in terms of the goods and services tax which is being discussed in public debate in Australia it would apply to a number of things which are areas of high consumer expenditure, such as clothing and food, which are exempted from some goods and services taxes overseas and which are not subject to wholesale sales tax in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the first part of the question, the compensation package would be an effort to compensate for the additional burden imposed on ordinary Australians by the introduction of a goods and services tax. The honourable senator then asked me about the inflationary effects of this. There has been an estimate of 4.4 per cent as an inflationary impact of the introduction of a goods and services tax. That has already changed. That was last week's estimate.

When one adds higher tobacco and health costs, and the more recently discovered road user costs, to the estimates of inflation in a consumption tax situation in Australia, the rate of inflation goes up considerably. Indeed, the Opposition, through its major articulate spokesman on this, Dr Hewson—who seems to be the only one who knows much about it on the Opposition side—is conceding that it will need a system of road user charges to replace part of the abolished petrol excise, an admission which carries with it serious doubts about the inflation assumption underlying the document. Might I just say that the inflationary effect is claimed to be a one-off effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to rule that the Leader of the Government is speculating in his answer and in fact does not know what he is talking about. The very point I made at the beginning, when the Minister was rising, was that this question would be rightly directed not to the Leader of the Government in the Senate but to the Leader of the Opposition, who knows what he is talking about and who can vouch for what the Opposition is believing and what the Opposition is saying.

—Senator Teague is saying, `This is our package for the people of Australia, and nobody is allowed to talk about it'. —Order! Senator Teague rose to take a point of order. There was no point of order, and I am sure that he knows that. It is impossible for the Chair to judge whether there is accuracy or truthfulness in answers to questions or during speeches in the Senate. I said it yesterday; I repeat it.

—In answer to a serious question from Senator Kernot, I was going on to say that the one-off inflationary effects as claimed—if I might be allowed to make a comment about the precious little package of the Liberal Party—will not be one-off. They will linger in the system, as every effect of depreciation of the dollar has lingered in the system, for a time far beyond that estimated by most academic economists. I think that is an important consideration.

PARA.TAB: As for any results concerning the adequacy of the compensation package, which the honourable senator asked me about, certainly we will make that material available to the Democrats and to anybody else who wants to listen.
Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Suddenly it doesn't suit you.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters gave a speech on what was supposed to be a supplementary question and there were nine bogus points of order, not one of which could possibly have been upheld by any President since Federation—not one. PARA.TAB: This is an absolutely spurious attempt to undermine the credibility of what otherwise might have been a bona fide contingency notice of motion. There might have been days in which it was worth pulling it on but there has never been a day less appropriate than today.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion, basically to extend Question Time, I point out that what the Senate is certainly aware of is a range of facts, rather than the quaint assertions that the Government has been making. The fact is that we got five questions up today for one very simple reason: the answers, which in most cases bore very little relevance to the question, went on and on.

PARA.TAB: Points of order were taken, for example, about Senator Collins who, until the last 30 seconds of his answer, had not addressed anything to do with the question raised by Senator Newman, which was specifically about tourist operators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was sat down on three points of order from an Opposition question.

PARA.TAB: If the Ministry sets out on a deliberate policy of taking eight minutes to answer a question and then does not in fact answer it, it is natural that there will be points of order and objections from the Opposition, because that is a deliberate and determined policy by the Government of disrupting Question Time. When Government senators were aware we had that document they did what they could to make certain we could not continue our questioning on that issue. I am not revealing a dead secret: we have more questions about that, which clearly the Government does not want to answer.

I conclude by saying this: yes, we are overjoyed to have a debate, but I tell the Government that, if it insists on turning Question Time into debates and deliberately restricts the amount of time the Opposition has to ask questions, for which, judging by today's performance, it appears to have no answers, then we will continue, naturally, to take points of order and to express our concern that this Government is deliberately setting about avoiding answering questions because, frankly, it does not have the answers. TALK.START.PARA: —Christmas is looking pretty good at this time.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I only intend to be very brief to make a point of disagreement with Senator Coulter on the matter that he has just raised. Whenever a bad performance is put in, it should be analysed immediately because the recognition of such—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The expressions `shut up' and `sit down' are being used consistently during Question Time from both sides of the chamber.

—I rise in support of Senator Hill's motion. It is a useful motion to have at this time. —Marge, you will never have to answer one.

—I note that Lurch has interjected. —I support Senator Hill's motion to suspend Standing Orders because we have seen displayed yesterday and today a failing government that is not able to answer questions in the Senate and is therefore evading giving those answers. PARA.TAB: When the Government has attempted to face only five Opposition questions, with all the evasion and extra pressure that comes when there is an attempt to misrepresent what the Opposition is saying, it is no wonder that the Opposition is seeking that the Government live up to its duty to the Parliament and to the people of Australia and answer questions—the same number of questions that we would normally expect the government of the day to answer.

I believe that it is appropriate that we suspend Standing Orders so that this failing Government is brought into a position where it is seen by the Senate and the public to have been required to answer the questions and give its account for its failures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have this to say about the number of questions asked during Question Time: the reason that we have a President to make decisions is that sometimes people on the other side interpret their questions in one way and we interpret them in another way. PARA.TAB: When Senator Walters, a great senator in this chamber, asks Senator Button what are the costs of carrying out certain procedures, current circumstances convey an imputation and an inference that the Government has acted in some way dishonestly or immorally. If such an inference is contained in that sort of a question, we will get the sorts of answers that we are hearing. It is clear that Ministers can and do give such answers. Honourable senators have to expect that time will be taken up if a Minister, in answering imputations of inferences in a question, has to deal with political ploys such as ridicule and laughter—and at times, this is the way in which debate is conducted across the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need to implement the Coalition's Fightback Program offering vision, hope and jobs to the millions of Australians who have suffered under the ruinous years of Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to remind the Senate of a few of the points contained in the Opposition's Fightback! document, which contains 600 pages of substance, a framework for returning Australia to prosperity. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, commences by giggling, as is his wont in these situations. This document provides a blueprint that can rebuild and reward Australia. It is to be compared with the ruinous years of Labor. Sadly, that will be the way that this Government will be recorded by so many Australians, so many who have suffered, who have had their dreams shattered, who have lost jobs, who have gone through the agony of seeing children unable to find employment—the so-called workers of the workers' party who have had their aspirations crushed.

PARA.TAB: Our package, the 600 pages of substance that the Minister wishes to dismiss so lightly, can now be answered by him. It has been on the table for a week and this Government has been unable to mount any attack whatsoever against it. This will be an opportunity for the Government to put down a considered counterposition. We will await with interest what the Minister puts today as the Government's answer to this substance. This substance must be contrasted with that which the Government now offers.

I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, of the pitiful answer the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) put just over a week ago in this Parliament, which he referred to as his jobs statement. It was his answer to what he said was the nation's jobs crisis. It was an answer which was much more concerned with his own job crisis; an answer which offered no structural reform for this country, which is so desperately needed; an answer that gave no incentive for business to increase investment and to increase job opportunities; and an answer that did not deal with the major issues that have been so difficult for this Government, such as Coronation Hill, Wesley Vale and the uranium policy—the illogical aspects of the Government's policies which it is happy to acknowledge are illogical but which it cannot correct because of the difficulties within its own show.

The jobs statement was a package that offered no chance of sustainable jobs and no genuine job opportunities whatsoever. It certainly put a little bit more money back into training. Training people is worth while but they are going to need jobs at the end of it and the Government offered no hope for that.

That miserable contribution has to be contrasted with what the Opposition put down last week which, for the first time, offers hope, offers vision and offers two million jobs before the end of this decade. It is the substance of this package that we want debated. We have said to the Government that we are prepared to debate it. We will debate it over and over again for the next 12 or 18 months until the Government is prepared to go to the people—and the people will pass their judgment.

What is the background to the Government's non-answer to our alternative, which offers hope for the future? What is the scene in contemporary Australia at the moment? What will be the legacy that Labor leaves? There are one million people presently unemployed. That excludes all those who have become so dispirited that they have left the job market and all those who are working just a few hours a week, which many estimate to include up to another half a million. So 1 1/2 million Australians are either unemployed or underemployed—the legacy of Labor. What does it mean for young people in this country, 30 per cent of whom are unemployed? That is excluding this year's school leavers joining that sorry list. How is this described by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe)? In typical Labor terms of the class struggle, he defines it as the `class of the new poor'—the unemployed, the underemployed and the young people who now have no hope under Labor.

We have the worst job insecurity situation in 60 years. That will be the legacy of the Hawke Labor Government, an important part of which is the Minister who is going to respond here today and put his Government's answer to this substantial package.

The picture gets worse: it gets worse in terms of the length of time that these people are unemployed. Whilst a year ago 13 weeks was the mean average time of unemployment, it is now 26 weeks. The picture continues to deteriorate. What of those people who have managed to maintain employment, who have been able to cling to jobs through this period of Labor Government? Their position is pretty miserable as well, because they are now taking home $20 a week less than when Labour came to government. Their standard of living has dropped under Labor.

Those who are out of work have obviously suffered most, but those who are in work have also suffered due to falling standards of living. That is the Labor legacy. That is what Labor has given to ordinary working Australians. That is what Mr Hawke refers to as sharing the burden, sharing the price for something that one day will be better. But the one day when it will be better has not come about and the position has further deteriorated.

Let us look very briefly at the position of the nation as a whole. By 1989 foreign debt had exploded to a massive 61 per cent of GDP. That is well ahead of Brazil, Mexico and these other countries with enormous debt. It is higher in terms of total debt, debt per capita and even debt as a percentage of GDP. That is where the nation stands at the moment. That will be another part of the legacy of Labor.

This, of course, is the achievement of the precious accord, which has principally had the effect of restraining productivity. It is no surprise that under Labor productivity in this country has been near the bottom of the OECD table and well behind that of our neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region. Why has it got so bad? Is it just the accord? No, it is not just the accord; it is the Government's approach to taxation.

The contrast is so vivid between our package and the Government's approach to taxation. I remind the Senate that the total tax take under Labor has risen some 34 per cent since 1983. This package will turn that around and give back to Australians the tax that they would have had to pay under Labor. It will provide them with some incentive to do better for themselves and for their families.

It is not just a matter of total tax take but what has happened to the total tax rate as it applies to ordinary Australians. We now find that the top marginal rate comes into effect when only 1.25 times average male earnings is reached. So, under Labor, ordinary Australian workers on average male earnings are now just under the level at which they will attract the top marginal rate. That has been Labor's legacy. That has been the disincentive that has crushed people and has put them out of work by putting their employers out of work. The people will not forget it. They also will not forget because we will not let them. Bracket creep—the hidden tax—has ripped $22 billion off Australian taxpayers since the Hawke Government came to power. Of course, the contrast is again as stark as ever with the package put down by Dr Hewson. Those things will not happen under the next coalition government.

I remind the Senate of what has happened to fuel taxes. I suppose Senator Button is going to refer to fuel taxes. We thought those opposite would yesterday but they backed off. In 1983 Federal petrol tax was just 9c a litre; now under Labor it is 26c a litre. The alternative is in the Liberal-National coalition's Fightback package.

What has been the achievement of Labor? There must have been an achievement. The greatest achievement, which Senator Alston will remind the Senate about, is in the expansion of welfare. It is the fastest growing area of Budget outlays under the Labor Government; the Government has had the gall to boast about this growth in welfare. In this country of opportunity, $30 billion a year is now spent on welfare, largely because people are out of jobs—and more of them are being pushed into the position where they have no choice but to turn to the state for help.

It is a tragic situation, and it has driven us to provide a real and substantial alternative—a total package that can give people hope and opportunity for the future. I refer to people in those businesses that have been driven out of operation by Labor's record real interest rates, who have suffered from the recession that we had to have—the legacy of the former Treasurer, who no doubt will soon be back as head of the Labor Party—who have been driven out of business under the record number of bankruptcies in this miserable period of Labor government. I refer to people—not only young people—who have wanted the opportunity to better themselves. Everyone knows that the higher the qualifications the better chance of getting a job. We find that some 30,000 people last year were turned away from tertiary study in this country. Again, Labor's policies have failed to provide opportunities for young people to better themselves.

That is why in our package we refer to this as Labor's human misery because so much misery has resulted from failed policies and a Government that has not been able to get it right and has had too long to get it right. It has led to so many Australians feeling helpless; so much despair in our community, which is demonstrated in all the opinion polls that are taken; and so many Australians who are concerned for their children and their grandchildren. For the first time, an Australian generation has the prospect of leaving to its successors a depressing legacy of a lower standard of living than it inherited.

That is the background. That is Labor's record of so-called achievement. It is against that background that we have put our alternative, which we submit is a radical alternative; we do not shy away from that. It is a challenging alternative for the Australian people. It is a massive alternative in that it encompasses so many areas of responsibility of government and gives Australians a real opportunity.

It is, above all, a strategy for jobs and growth—the two big areas of failure by this Government. It is a strategy that has been designed and independently assessed to provide two million jobs by the end of the decade and to give people a chance again. It is a strategy that will give us the opportunity to commence the massive task of retiring government debt. It is calculated to retire some $13 billion of government debt. Even there one sees the contrast. When this Government sells assets it puts the money straight into general revenue, which is expended on its programs. Under our package, when we sell assets the money will be used to retire debt.

How will we stimulate Australia to embrace these new opportunities? We will do it with the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history: a 30 per cent reduction in income tax—round about $13 billion that Australian taxpayers will not have to pay in the form of income tax. Nothing could be done by a government to lift incentive more dramatically and to encourage Australians to work that extra hour, stay for that extra hour of overtime and do that bit more, because they will gain a benefit with which they can benefit their families in turn.

We will abolish seven taxes: the whole of the wholesale sales tax, $9.4 billion; and the whole of the payroll tax, which Senator Button yesterday tried to dismiss as being simply a subject that we were talking about, $5.8 billion. That money will be paid to the States, provided the States abolish payroll tax. The petroleum products excise—another $6.6 billion—will go. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that 55 per cent of that excise falls on business and this package has a lot to do with giving business the opportunity to grow and employ people. The superannuation lump sum tax will go; the customs duties will be phased out by the year 2000; and Labor's training guarantee levy will go—the typical way of Labor which is to compel rather than encourage an outcome. The coal export duty will go as well. Seven of Labor's taxes will go.

There will be significant cuts in the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. Changes to the capital gains tax to provide significant tax relief, and incentives and retirement benefits for small business people, farmers and investors are part of this package. The roll-over procedures—which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would now be familiar with and which the people who are interested in staying in business and building their businesses will appreciate—are a part of this package.

It is a goods and services tax, yes, but a goods and services tax which will broaden the tax base, tax the black economy and get some revenue from those who do not pay tax at the moment. It will tax foreign tourists—we cannot see any reason why foreign tourists should not pay their fair share—and it will enable us to slash taxes on business inputs and exports; just where it should be correctly targeted. It is much lamented that it is difficult to overcome the poor record of national savings, but we address that issue in this package. There are tax concessions for long term savings through a new voluntary and fairer superannuation scheme, and incentives for shorter term savings through a new tax-free savings scheme. So we can go on.

But it is not only that. I have condemned Labor's failure to provide education opportunities for young people. This package gives hope to young people who want a better education than they have been able to get under Labor. That does not mean an education which provides a fair or reasonable standard but an education standard that is up with the best in the world. As Senator Button should know, we live in a highly competitive region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that right?

—If the Minister does not know that by now, he should. Second best is not good enough. Too often in this country, second best has been good enough. It has been good enough for this Government, which has kept 30,000 Australians who have wanted that opportunity out of tertiary study. They will get that opportunity under the Fightback package being put forward by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: It provides new incentives and initiatives for the unemployed. It is no good just paying pensions to the unemployed and giving them a reward in order to sustain life. They want hope, jobs and opportunities. We provide a new flexibility to give that to them. Senator Alston has raised that issue in the Senate and will continue to do so.

We do not forget families. Coalition governments will never forget families, who are their first priority. Families will gain, particularly those at the lower and middle income levels. The key target areas of this package are the lower to middle income areas. They are the areas that need and will get support under this package—particularly, family allowances, which will double for lower income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Because they need it. Because they need to keep kids, because they need to support their families, and because we are interested in their families.
—As compensation for your GST.

—They get more than compensation for a GST. They get some recognition of their responsibility to their children—which is more than they get from the Government. So families will be a target. The lower and middle income earners are a particular target because we want to give them an incentive and an opportunity to do better for themselves and then they can do better for their country.

PARA.TAB: It will mean an end to the tax bracket creep which I mentioned a moment ago; an end to Labor's hidden tax. It will mean an end to the automatic indexation of excise which, again, has ripped billions of dollars from Australian taxpayers without their realising that it has been occurring. We will have the guts to come to the Parliament if we wish to increase excise. We will not, as this Government has done, index it and increase it automatically every six months.

Therefore, we put before the Australian people a huge integrated package. It must be looked at as a whole. It is a package which presents a way to rebuild and reward Australia. It works for no favourites; it abandons all of Labor's notions of supporting vested interests. It attacks tax avoidance measures which still exist in the superannuation area and in other areas. It provides a brand new health policy which can remedy so many of the faults contained in Labor's health policy. It will get rid of the queues and get people transferred out of the public system where they cannot get a bed and put them into the private system where beds are available. It counters overservicing, it provides choice, it is honest to our philosophy, and it will be to the benefit of the Australian people.

The Australian people will need time to absorb 600 pages of detail. But we say that they will see within this package a structure that will enable them to have hope for the future and will give them a better chance to have a job in the future and to find a way out of their current misery. As I have said, in doing so, they will be not only benefiting themselves and their families but also benefiting this nation. I commend the coalition's Fightback package to the Australian community and to the Senate. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be hearing a lot more of it, and I suspect that by the end we will convince even you of its benefits.
