TALK.START.PARA: —That all sounds pretty good. It is good on rhetoric and not too good on substance. It is like the rest of this package. Let us look at the wording of this urgency motion. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to implement the Coalition's Fightback Program offering vision, hope and jobs to the millions of Australians who have suffered under the ruinous years of Labor.

There is a lot of rhetoric in that statement. It begins by seeking to capitalise on current unemployment levels because it refers to the hope, vision and `the ruinous years of Labor'. The very weaknesses of this package are explained in Senator Hill's speech. What will happen? According to Senator Hill, everybody in Australia will gain if a Liberal Party government were to be elected to office: 30,000 students will gain, families will gain, and workers will gain. That is the rhetoric which we have been given. For Senator Hill to talk about 30,000 students gaining from a political party which had the lowest education participation rates in the OECD when this Government came to office is just bunkum.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition is using rhetoric in laying the groundwork for this package. Talking about rhetoric, I will start with the man who would be Treasurer in an alternative government. In August and September this year, Mr Reith, the man who would be Treasurer, talked about the black economy—

TALK.START.PARA: —He will be Treasurer.

—I know that Senator Macdonald does not want to hear this; but I listened in silence to Senator Hill. Mr Reith talked about $40 billion which would be gained from the black economy—from income tax which is being avoided by various people. In September he said, `Wherever you look in this country, you find great experts at cheating'. I must say that it is a sorry outlook for any government of this country if that is the alternative Treasurer's view.

PARA.TAB: In September and October, we were told that $40 billion was going to be reefed from the black economy by an alternative government. I suspect that Dr Hewson is a more rigorous and honest man than is the alternative Treasurer. In the package which was announced last week, that figure has suddenly become $4 billion. There are assumptions behind the $40 billion figure and assumptions behind the $4 billion figure, none of which are capable of being tested. But the $4 billion figure is absolutely integral to the Opposition's proposed package.

It is very strange that this package comes from an Opposition which opposed the capital gains tax which was introduced by this Government and which was to underpin the income tax system in this country; an Opposition which opposed the fringe benefits tax; and an Opposition which opposed the assets test. Suddenly, the Opposition has decided that it will keep all of those things. Somehow, the measures that it opposed during the life of this Government are suddenly good things. With respect to the black economy, it says that the GST will capture all the rest.

There is a lot of rhetoric in this debate, particularly from Senator Hill and in the wording of this motion. As I have said, we are used to rhetoric from Liberal Party oppositions. Think of the rhetoric of Malcolm Fraser.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is John Hewson.
—All right, Senator—we will come to him. Malcolm Fraser said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal and National Country parties have prepared a far reaching program to restore prosperity and to give effect to our philosophy of freedom, opportunity and concern for the individual.

He said, `We have a strategy to restore prosperity'. That was the rhetoric of the Fraser years; a rhetoric which was unmatched by any performance in terms of financial deregulation, tax reform and tariffs. The Opposition now says, `We are different from the earlier generation of Liberals because we have the guts. We lacked it last time but this time we have guts'. A lot of Liberals who were part of the Fraser years are still with us. Mr Howard, Mr Peacock, Dr Hewson, who was then an adviser, and Senator Michael Baume are still here. Dr Hewson talks about generational change as an incitement to his back bench. Perhaps he is holding out promises to people such as Dr Kemp in order to incite them to get to the front bench.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the rhetoric and the reality, let us look at the much vaunted table on page 342 of the Opposition's document. It is a very interesting table to analyse. I commend it to Senator Hill because everything he said takes very little account of that key table in the document which has been given a fair degree of publicity. The table compares three average annual growth rates in this country—the 1970s, the 1980s and the potential growth rate if this alleged package of the coalition is implemented.
What is the worst column of all in relation to all of these figures? It is the 1970s when the coalition was in government. The average growth in GDP through that period was 2.65.

TALK.START.PARA: —The worst column is the base case column. It is a continuation of present policy.

PARA.TAB: Senator BUTTON—I understand. In terms of actual measured performance, the worst column is the period when those opposite were in government. The Opposition cannot run away from that. But just look at what the column containing the Opposition's projections means—the so-called high road; and I assume that the Opposition thinks it can take the high road rather than the low road. Look at the high road in respect of a number of important indicators and match it with the rhetoric of Senator Hill's speech.
Look at the high road with respect to employment. Senator Hill has said that the Opposition will establish two million jobs by the year 2000—easy rhetoric! But look at the highroad scenario.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have certainly travelled the low road.

—Oh, Elmer, that is an absolutely stunning interjection. Look at the high road. The high road is a straight line projection, in terms of employment, of Labor's `ruinous years'—up to the mid quarter of 1990. From 1983 to 1990, at the time of the onset in the recession, the employment projections are exactly the same. It is a straight line projection to the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: Look at the projections in terms of unemployment. Again, there is almost a straight line projection to the year 2000. This is an Opposition document which Senator Hill clearly has not studied. Look at projections in terms of exports up to the year 2000. There is absolutely no gain in export performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —You thought it was a good package.
—Senator Kemp wanted to debate this package; he should listen so that he can do so. He should look at the Opposition's document.
—What are your alternatives?

—Under the Opposition's motion, we are asked to look at the Opposition's document. In terms of unemployment and employment, Senator Hill should look at the Opposition's document before he makes these wordy, heady speeches. He should look at the Opposition's own projections—the projections that will produce nirvana in Australia; that will produce the same scenario in terms of unemployment and employment; that will produce a worse scenario in terms of exports; and, in terms of productivity—God! How many times have we debated productivity in this place?—a worse performance.
—You have the worst productivity performance in history.

—I will tell the honourable senator what the Opposition's document says. Over the 10 years it factors in approximately a 4.5 per cent productivity growth, coming out of the recession, which is the product of this Government. But it still arrives at an average productivity rate which is lower than that of the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: I ask Australian Democrat senators, who I think probably have an intelligent interest in this topic, to look at some of these projections when they hear the heady analyses given by people such as Senator Hill. If they look at the investment projections they will see that a marginally better performance is foreshadowed. But they should look at the qualitative investment figures; they should look at the very high figure for private sector dwelling investment. Do people who are concerned about the comparative position of this country in the world want to see such a high investment figure? We want to see quality investment in manufacturing and service industries leading to jobs and exports, not investment as high as that in the housing sector.

So much for the reference in the motion to the `ruinous Labor years'. If we look at the projected figures, we can see that the Opposition is attempting to capitalise on the recession and, apart from that, project the sorts of figures which this Government obtained through the 1980s.

I come to the Fightback! document. Senator Hill draws my attention to the number of pages. I must say that it is a curate's egg of a document—a lot of it will go bad. It is riddled with popular phrases. Even in the title Taxation and Expenditure Reform for Jobs and Growth there are some mighty assumptions, some mighty non sequiturs, and very much a mixture of dubious, unspecified assumptions, which have been described by commentators alternatively as bogus, specious, doubtful, nonsense and problematical. These are adjectives that have been used about assumptions made in the document.

The first thing to be said about the document is that it is very much a Hewson document—Dr Hewson, the reluctant leader of the Liberal Party and former adviser to a failed government. What he is seeking to do with this document is to lift a lacklustre, dull, desultory Opposition to a position where it might attain government. I hesitate to quote Shakespeare to those opposite, but in Henry IV, part 1, Glendower says, `I can summon spirits from the vasty deep', and Hotspur says, `Yes, but will they come?'. That is what Dr Hewson is trying to do and it is what this package is all about. It is Dr Hewson trying to summon spirits from the vasty deep, and will they come? I congratulate Dr Hewson on trying to lift a lacklustre, desultory Opposition to a position where it looks like an alternative government. The last leader of an Opposition to do that in Australia was Gough Whitlam.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about Bob Hawke? You are dumping on the Prime Minister again. There will be more questions in Question Time tomorrow.

—You are all talk. As I was saying, the last person to do that was Gough Whitlam, who lifted an Opposition to a position of government. In government, the quality of the team becomes very important. That is one of the first difficulties that the Hewson package faces, because the quality of the team in administering such a package would be immensely important.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! I appeal to colleagues on my left for a little bit of quiet.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he does tempt us, doesn't he?
—Senator Walters, I have just asked for quiet.

—I thought those opposite wanted a debate about this matter. Obviously they do not; they just want to yell their heads off. The third point I want to make about the package is to issue a warning. Dr Hewson, the man who is to lift this desultory Opposition, is an academic economist. One thing academic economists are not good at is behavioural assumptions; they are not behavioural scientists. The slogan inherent in this package is that if one changes the tax mix everything else will follow. That is the unstated assumption. That is an extraordinarily narrow view and I warn those opposite against this experience. Academic economists have misled governments about the J-curve, twin deficits, the application of monetary policy and again this package. All the assumptions are very questionable. Therefore, I utter a note of caution. All the assumptions appeal to those opposite because during the 1980s they obtained a great deal of succour from admiring Margaret Thatcher and saying, `Why can't we be like that in Australia?'.
—Did she plan a recession?

—Yes, she created one. Just look at the unemployment figures in England. The view of those opposite was, `If only we had a leader like Margaret Thatcher; if only we had not had a leader like Malcolm Fraser'. If only they had tackled some of the assumptions that existed in other countries, then this collection of B-grade Babbitts that constitute the Opposition would have been in a much better position. One has this sort of double whammy of an academic economist mixed with a lacklustre team which presumably would try to administer this package.

PARA.TAB: This involves matching the reality of the Australian economy with an academic package. What are the realities of the Australian economy at present in respect of two key indicators, for example—low inflation and high exports? What does the Opposition offer? It offers higher inflation and lower net exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—That is what it offers—read the table in the document.
—Tell us about your economic model.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I have been interrupted all through my speech. If those opposite cannot take it, they should go outside. It is clear from the document itself that the rich will benefit more: the largest gains will go to the top 2 per cent who pay taxes. That is clear from the document. —We are going to end it.

—Oh, you are to end bracket creep. That is terrific. PARA.TAB: As for the consumption tax itself, when a consumption tax has been introduced overseas it has always gone up. One gets the compensation package when it is first introduced, but when the consumption tax goes up in subsequent years, as it has gone up in many countries, one does not get the compensation. One gets a one-off, but not when taxes go up as they have in the past. The Canadian experience has been that the price reductions have not been passed onto the consumer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Button, the time for your contribution has expired.
—Might I conclude on this note, Madam Acting Deputy President—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hill's matter of urgency, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to implement the coalition's Fightback program offering vision, hope and jobs to the millions of Australians who have suffered under the ruinous years of Labor.

It even has the support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because he endorsed a consumption tax in 1985. He said that he believed that Mr and Mrs Australia wanted a fairer tax system and a more efficient system and that they would respond positively to the proposal. Even Wayne Goss, the Premier of Queensland, said:
I supported the consumption tax at the tax summit because it is so efficient. The sort of tax that could sweep away a number of inefficient and expensive ways to collect taxes . . .

And so he went on. I say to the Australian Democrats that they will be among the few people in Australia who do not support the package. The package has had wide endorsement from all sections of the community. I warn the Australian Democrats that if they stand in the way of this package it will be like standing in front of an avalanche. They will be swept out of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I listened to Senator Button. I think it is one of the few times that Senator Button has come into a debate in this Parliament over the last three years. Normally he handballs the problems to Senator McMullan and Senator McMullan gives the Government's position. After listening to Senator Button, that is probably the way to go because all Senator Button did was to take us on a trip down memory lane. His speech had no substance. He gave no alternatives. In fact, even his opposition to the proposal was very ineffective. There is no doubt that over the last 12 months this Government has made three attempts to stimulate some sort of support for itself. Every attempt has failed. The currency has been devalued, as the Government goes further on. I refer to the March industry statement Building a Competitive Australia. Then there was the Budget. Twelve days ago we had the employment statement. All we have had is an absolute failure of Government policies.

We have to look at this against the background of what is happening in Australia. We have to see against what background we are putting forward this new Fightback proposition. For goodness sake, there is not one person in Australia of any intelligence at all who would say that the Government's policies are working. We have a gross foreign debt of $166 billion. That debt has increased from $36 billion since 1982-83. The current account deficit of $15.5 billion was $7 billion in 1982-83. Bankruptcies have increased by 72 per cent—from 5,151 in 1982-83 to 13,849 in 1990-91. Unemployment has now increased to 867,200. Unemployment, in fact, has never been below 6 per cent in the time that this Government has been in office.

It is no wonder that all Australians have embraced this package. Australians realise that it gives them some hope. They realise that there will have to be some marked shift away from the Government's policies and a marked difference between the policies which the Government is offering and the policies which the coalition is putting forward. I have gone out into rural Australia, as have my colleagues Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator O'Chee. We have gone to many meetings since the tax package was launched. All I can say is that I have not found one person to whom I have spoken who has not embraced the package. All Australians know that we are on the road to disaster.

People are worried about their children not being able to get a job; they are worried about their own farms; they are worried about their own businesses. They know the phones are not ringing; there are no orders coming in; storemen and packers are standing around with their hands in their pockets waiting for something to do; and there are 3,000 people turning up for 70 jobs that are not even advertised.

What better word picture does Senator Walsh want to prove to him that Labor's eight or nine years in government have been a total, miserable failure? People who trusted the Labor Party have been disappointed. It cannot point to one position that it has come back with and say that it has provided jobs, that it has provided a future, that it has provided any hope for anyone. The Labor Party's unionists and workers are the people who have been the worst hit. There are now fewer and fewer people paying for more and more people as they go onto unemployment benefit. Those are the indisputable facts that face Australia at the moment. Thirty-four per cent of people are now placed on some sort of government assistance. That is what Australia faces at the moment.

Let us look at some of the things that this package does. Let us just examine it. Let us look at the benefits for rural Australia. It gives a 26c reduction in diesel and petrol prices; that is a saving of $6.6 billion. That is going to reduce freight costs by around $2 billion. There will be no sales tax and no payroll tax. The payroll tax is an iniquitous tax, the very worst tax that has ever been thrust on Australians—a tax on employment. Let me just examine that in the context of primary industry. In an abattoir it costs $120 to bone out a beast. The payroll tax on that $120 is about 6 per cent. For every beast that is boned out in an abattoir, there will be a saving for primary industry and farmers of $6 per beast.

The isolated children's boarding allowance will increase. These are the sorts of issues that the women in rural Queensland and rural Australia really appreciate. There will be no assets test for Austudy or family allowance in hardship conditions. There will be no assets test for isolated children, and no assets test for retirees living on a family farm.

What absolute misery the action of placing an assets test on a family farm has caused decent farmers who have spent all their lives working on their properties and are now wanting to pass those properties on to their children. They have been forced to sell the property and retire in a town. That is a major problem that Senator Walsh should be able to recognise because he is a man who has spent much of his life on the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —How he could let those types of policies that impact so heavily on family farmers creep into the Labor Party—
—They should have been tougher.

—One can see why Senator Walsh is a social outcast in rural Australia when he makes those sorts of statements. He ought to be thoroughly ashamed of what he does. But let us look at some of the personal income taxes that we are offering in this package. If anyone is to work—and people want to work—there has to be some sort of incentive for them to get out there and do it. We are offering the average Australian on an income of between $25,000 and $30,000 an additional $1,500 in his pay package. We are lowering the tax rates from 20 per cent to 16 per cent, from 39 per cent to 30 per cent and from 45 per cent to 36 per cent. Ninety-five per cent of taxpayers will pay no more than 30c in the dollar. Superannuation lump sum tax will go. The petroleum product excise will be abolished. All those things are going to encourage business. Personal income tax has increased by 30 per cent. Now people earning only 1.25 times average male earnings are paying tax at the rate of 38 per cent. That will be reduced.

PARA.TAB: They are positive aspects that we are offering. No-one can dispute those. They are a new direction. They are being sought by Australia. Everyone in Australia is worried. People with children are worried that their children will not be able to get a job when they leave school at the end of this year. If they have a job themselves, they are worried because they are seeing the person at the next desk or on the next machine losing his job and they are wondering when their turn is coming, when the bell is going to toll for them.

What have we heard from Senator Button? He has given us no direction. He has indicated no way in which the Labor Party will increase job opportunities for the average Australian. All we have heard is a diatribe and attack on the coalition's Fightback! paper.

The Labor Party is going to have to do better, or it will be swept out of office at the next election. Already the polls are indicating a 20 per cent gap between the coalition and the Labor Party. As a student of politics, I know that a government never recovers once there is a gap of more than 15 or 16 per cent. The Labor Party can never pick up from that. It just does not have the firepower in the front bench. It is a tired Government. It is a Government that has run out of vision. It has run out of ideas.

Senator Button, when asked in an interview whether he was going to stand for election again, said, `Thank goodness, not again'. Senator Walsh, who did have some capacity in the front bench, wants to retire. He is becoming lead in the saddle of the Labor Party. All he can do is get on television and bucket the leader. Where is the thrust, where is the attack from the Labor Party to overhaul the coalition? It is just not there. The Labor Party is going to go down the way of all governments that let unemployment run at over one million people, over 10 per cent, that run out of ideas. The people will reject the Labor Party at the next election. There is no doubt about that.

The coalition's Fightback package will encourage investment. It will stimulate savings and it will create jobs. I do not know how many jobs it will create, but I know one thing and I know it for certain: it is going to create more jobs than this incapacitated Government will create with all its policy positions, with the three papers that it has put down in the last 12 months. They have had no response. The coalition's Fightback package will put Australia right on the path. It will see an end to the disastrous policies of this discredited Federal Government, and it will replace them with hope and vision for Australia. It will give our youth a real chance to get jobs which will be sustainable and meaningful, and it will be there in the next five, 10 and 20 years.

I suggest that the Democrats, if they know what is good for them, will support this package. If they do not, they will be doing a King Canute trying to turn the tide back. It did not work for King Canute, and it will not work for anyone else who stands in the way of this package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the urgency motion moved by the Opposition this afternoon about its so-called Fightback program which, it claims, offers vision, hope and jobs for the Australian community. I was very surprised by Senator Hill's speech at the opening of this debate. Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, was actually calling for a watering down of the capital gains tax in Australia. On a number of occasions in his speech he referred to the need to change the capital gains tax in Australia. I simply remind the Senate that in September 1981 when Senator Hill made his maiden speech in this place—which I have read very carefully—he called for the introduction of a capital gains tax in Australia. He was out of step with the Liberal Party at the time, he claimed that there was a need for a capital gains tax in Australia, and now today we see him calling for the watering down of the capital gains tax.

PARA.TAB: Central to the Opposition policy in this package is the goods and services tax, but I intend to dispose of the cosmetic language and refer to it as a consumption tax or a value added tax—VAT. It is a VAT levied at multi stages. A well-known Australian said of VAT a while back:

SPEECH.PARA: A multi-stage VAT was rejected fairly quickly because it would have imposed an enormous paperwork burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities.
That very well-known Australian went on to say:

We concluded that therefore, if we were to broaden the indirect tax base, the simplest method would be to extend the existing wholesale sales tax to some goods now exempt and impose a tax on selected services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Senator Walsh asks who that was. It was not Bob Hawke and it certainly was not the Treasurer, John Kerin; it was in fact John Howard, the last Liberal Treasurer of Australia in the Fraser Government in 1981, who said in his major taxation statement to the House of Representatives that a VAT would impose an enormous paperwork burden on Australian taxpayers and collecting authorities—red tape as a result of a VAT.

PARA.TAB: Last week, Mr Howard said that he had tried to persuade Mr Malcolm Fraser to introduce a VAT in Australia. So, on the one hand, in his taxation statement to Parliament he was saying that these taxes would result in red tape and, on the other hand, more recently he was saying that he tried to encourage Mr Malcolm Fraser to introduce one.

It is interesting that in Mr Howard's statement to Parliament he went on to talk about the difficulties of broadening taxes on commodities, and asked the very basic question as to `whether there should be any exemptions' from such a tax. Mr Howard raised the matter of whether basic foodstuffs should be exempted from an expenditure tax. He raised that explicitly in the House of Representatives in March 1981.

After making some changes to the tax system, Mr Howard in fact chose not to do so; he did not go ahead with a tax on basic foodstuffs. Nor did the Hawke Government. The Hawke Government has exempted the basic food items consumed by humans from sales tax in this country. But now we have Dr Hewson, the radical leading the charge, who wants a 15 per cent value added tax on food and virtually everything else consumed in the Australian economy.

This proposal, this centrepiece of the Liberal Party policy, is very draconian. It represents a very inflexible taxation proposal. This proposal is tougher than the value added tax in the United Kingdom. It is tougher than the value added tax operated under Mrs Thatcher, who was extremely right wing in her views. Mrs Thatcher, for all of her faults, did not allow the VAT in the United Kingdom to apply to food consumed in that country. The VAT introduced in Canada in January this year does not tax basic foodstuffs.

Here we have a proposal from the Liberal Party, saying that it offers hope and vision to the Australian community. These people, who have gone further than the conservative governments in other countries of the world, propose a draconian, inflexible tax, including a tax on the basic foodstuffs consumed by Australian people. It is a full-blooded draconian proposal.

This is the very tax that many hundreds of thousands of British born people came to Australia to escape. They fled the United Kingdom and came here to get away from the very type of tax that the Liberals want to introduce in this country. This is the very sort of tax that is ridiculed regularly and repeatedly on British television programs broadcast on Australian television as being a joke, as being all intrusive and as involving a tax inspector led recovery in the British economy.

I point out the shape of things to come under this proposal by the Liberals if they ever get elected to government. I have here the front cover of the Bulletin magazine. I should like to point out the masthead prices on the Bulletin magazine. They are here in black and white. They are not my figures; they are the publisher's figures on the Bulletin magazine. They show that in Australia this very magazine at the present time retails for $2.95. In New Zealand, where there is a consumption tax, a value added tax that the people opposite want to copy, the price is not $2.95 but in fact $5.95—for the very same magazine.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the exchange rate?

—Senator Short comes in on cue and asks about the exchange rate. We know about the exchange rate. New Zealand's economy is a basket case because of the idiotic policies that have been introduced there in recent years.
—What is their rate of exchange?

—The exchange rate happens to be $NZ1.38 to $A1. Its exchange rate is very poor. Even allowing for the exchange rate and for transport costs, the reality is that there is still a massive difference in the Australian price and the New Zealand price for this particular publication because, it says, the price in New Zealand is, `$5.95 incl. GST'.
—And you're saying it's all due to GST? What absolute nonsense.

—Senator Short parrots on, but I simply refer him to any newsagent or bookshop in this country. He should go in and have a look at the prices on books because he will see those prices published in black and white on their back covers. He will see that a typical paperback book retails in Australia for $9.99. The typical New Zealand price is not $9.99; it is $14.95 including GST. It is there in black and white in all the bookshops and newsagents in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the plan of the Liberals in some detail—this GST, as they call it in their sanitised language, which is really a VAT, a consumption tax. It wants a tax on goods and services at a 15 per cent rate basically at each stage of production in the production process in this country. This tax represents the first proposal for a comprehensive tax on services sold in the Australian economy.

It goes beyond taxing physical commodities to taxing services sold in the Australian economy. It will be a tax on electricity bills. It will be a tax on gas bills. It will be a tax on Telecom bills for telephones. It will be a tax on hairdressers. It will be a tax on car repairs. It will be a tax on accountants. A whole range of services will be taxed in this proposal. Virtually everything sold in this country will be taxed at 15 per cent.

This is a much more draconian proposal than that operated in the United Kingdom by that ultra conservative, Mrs Margaret Thatcher, because her tax was selective and flexible. Her tax allowed exemptions for foodstuffs. Her tax did not include a tax on gas bills. It did not include a tax on electricity bills. Dr Hewson wants a tax on those things. Her tax in the United Kingdom did not involve a tax on public transport fares. She did not tax bus fares or train fares. This proposal will do that. Mrs Thatcher also did not tax children's clothes. This proposal will tax children's clothes. I have already pointed out the impact of this proposal on the prices of books and publications sold in this country. In the United Kingdom they were not taxed.

In Canada, where the tax was brought in this year, there is no VAT on basic foodstuffs. But in Australia, under Dr Hewson, under the Liberals and under the National Party, which claims to represent the great food producing industries of Australia, there will be a tax on foodstuffs. There will be no exemptions for foodstuffs consumed in the Australian economy.

Let us look at some other countries where a VAT operates, such as France and Germany. They do not rely, as Dr Hewson would have us do, on a single, inflexible, non-selective tax rate of 15 per cent. Those countries make a policy decision that people should pay a higher rate of tax on luxury goods than on the basic necessities—the staple goods consumed by their citizens. They have a selective tax system with multiple tax rates. People in those countries pay a higher rate of tax for luxury goods than for the basic necessities. But under Dr Hewson, under the Liberals and Nationals, there would be a 15 per cent non-selective, non-targeted tax on virtually everything consumed in the Australian economy.

One of the great weaknesses of the proposal put up by the Liberals is its impact on inflation and price rises in the Australian community. They claim that somehow we would have an amazingly low 4.4 per cent rise in inflation as a result of their tax. Last year the Federal Treasury did an analysis of a 15 per cent consumption tax. Its figure showed a 7 per cent rise in inflation, although I admit that that was before any proposal came forward for a reduction in petrol prices.

We can also certainly say that since that time the Liberals have come out with a policy that would involve a rise in health charges for average Australian households. People would have to pay private health insurance. We know the impact of private health insurance on the consumer price index and inflation because we saw what happened in the mid-1980s when we encouraged Australians to go into Medicare, which had just been created. It resulted in a massive reduction in the consumer price index because health insurance costs were a major element of it.

One thing we have to bear in mind is that the Liberals somehow believe their rhetoric that a 15 per cent consumption tax collected at the retail level would have a lower effect on prices than the present 20 per cent wholesale sales tax. In many circumstances, that is a fallacious view. All we have to do is look at the profit mark-ups and the margins charged by businesses to see that, in many circumstances, the 15 per cent retail tax would lead to higher prices than the 20 per cent wholesale sales tax.

One of the really heroic assumptions made by the Liberals in this document—and we must really scrutinise these assumptions—is that somehow there is so much competition in the Australian economy that, if and when sales tax is abolished from goods sold in Australia, firms will automatically go out and lower their prices accordingly. The Liberals assume that somehow firms will do the right thing by the community and in every case lower their prices when sales tax is reduced. That is an heroic assumption and one that will not come true if such a proposal is introduced into this country.

One of the dreadful things about this proposal is how regressive it would be. The Liberals talked today about giving Australians vision and hope for the future. But this proposal is a tax on lower and middle income households. It is a very regressive tax and it will hit those households that spend all their incomes, because it is a tax on spending. The thing that is striking about lower income households is that they spend a disproportionately high amount of total income on food, clothing and footwear—32 per cent of all their income goes on food, clothing and footwear—and those areas are totally untaxed at the moment under the present wholesale sales tax. So food, clothing and footwear will see some of the biggest price rises in the Australian community if this crazy proposal is ever implemented.

Meanwhile, those on the highest incomes in the community spend only 9 per cent of their total income on food, clothing and footwear, so they will be affected less by the price rises under this type of proposal. It is absolutely unfair that, as a result of this proposal, staple goods—the basic household necessities of food, clothing and footwear—would go up in price while luxury goods would be reduced in price.

How can the Liberals justify massive falls in the price of luxury cars, gold watches, diamond tiaras or furs, which are the luxury goods consumed by the rich in our community? We tax them at a 30 per cent sales tax rate at present, but under the Liberals the tax would be reduced to a 15 per cent retail tax. Why is it that the Liberals want to have the same rate of tax for Mercedes and margarine, yoghurt and yachts, BMWs and bread?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want food exempt?

—I say to Senator Knowles that I know why: because they do not believe in social justice and they do not want fairness in the Australian community. They just want a massive transfer of wealth from middle and low income families to higher income families.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button also grossly mislead the Senate in the debate today. He did not say much at all. The one thing that he did say was that the assumption behind the coalition's proposals was that if we changed the tax mix everything else would follow. They have failed to comprehend that this is not just a matter of tax reform; this is an integrated package of proposals that range through tax reform, through reform of our health financing industry, through superannuation, through micro-economic reform, through the development of a new savings strategy and through an unashamedly pro-business approach to economic policy. Only by having a pro-business approach, only by removing the burdens and the costs that have so inhibited business in this country and have made it so uncompetitive with the rest of the world are we to provide hope, vision and opportunity and, most importantly of all, jobs for Australians.

We have a crisis in Australia of unprecedented magnitude, at least unprecedented in the past 60 years. We have seen progressively a major erosion in the living standards of all Australians. We have seen, and we are now seeing, nearly 1 1/2 million Australians unable to find the work they seek, and the level of employment amongst our young people is around 30 per cent. We have seen Australian families subjected to increasing pressures as a result of economic conditions.

We have seen Australia's foreign debt escalate from a figure of about $23 billion to a figure in excess of $130 billion in the eight years since this Government came to office. We have seen progressive undermining of our national productivity growth as a result of Labor's accord, which has kept wages down and in the end has resulted in record high unemployment. We have seen the tax burden on virtually all Australians rising over recent years to the stage where a person on only 15 to 20 per cent in excess of average weekly earnings is now hitting the top marginal tax rate. We have seen Australian business weighed down by increasing government regulation, high taxes, high real interest rates and a centralised wage system which have resulted in record bankruptcies, falling investment and fewer jobs. We have seen our education system, our training opportunities, failing to keep pace with the standards of the world's best.

We have to tackle that in this country if we are to hope ever to raise our living standards and our position in the internationally competitive stakes. If we do not do that we will continue down the progressive slide which has seen relative living standards in Australia—that is, relative to the standards in other industrialised and industrialising countries in the world—falling progressively for the past couple of decades. That is what we are about in this package.

We are about trying to turn Australia around so that the despair, the job loss, the lack of hope, the lack of vision and the lack of opportunity throughout the Australian community today—all summed up, perhaps, in one line: total lack of leadership—is reversed. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's new tax, which we have been debating this afternoon, has been named, for cosmetic and presentational reasons, a goods and services tax. In fact, it is a value added tax and I will refer to it correctly as a value added tax henceforth. The value added tax which the Opposition is proposing provides not so much a vision as a mirage. The Opposition's proposals contain a motley collection of false assumptions and fraudulent assertions.

PARA.TAB: The overwhelming false assumption is that Australia is a high tax country, especially a high income tax country. The fact is that, when looking at total taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product, Turkey is the only country which is unambiguously lower on the entire OECD scale than Australia, and the United States is lying about level with Australia. It is true that Australian governments raise a proportionately higher amount of their total revenue from income tax but, if we look at income tax revenue in isolation, Australia is still bordering on the bottom third of OECD countries. So the assumption that income tax is unsustainably high in Australia is demonstrably false.
The principal fraudulent assertion is that this change in the tax system will boost savings. Indeed, the executive summary in the document which was put out last week asserts:

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction of a 15 per cent Goods and Services Tax (with specific items zero-rated or exempt) that will:
. boost our national productivity and savings
That is an unambiguous fib, as Dr Hewson, in a previous mode, clearly acknowledged. In the Sydney Morning Herald on 13 April last year Dr Hewson said:
A 15 per cent across the board consumption tax . . . may only make a marginal effect on saving.

It has been pointed out that there are other measures in the Opposition's package which purport to boost savings, such as tax concessions on interest earnings, cash deposits and that sort of thing. The only thing one can be certain about with respect to those measures is that there will be public sector dissaving because of the income forgone from the interest rate concessions. Whether these measures do anything other than reorder the existing total pool of savings held by private individuals is suspect. When one puts those two things together, there is at least a strong possibility that those measures will lead to total dissaving rather than enhanced saving.

PARA.TAB: The other fraudulent assertion is the allegation that this value added tax will get rid of the allegedly damaging effects of payroll tax on the economy. I will deal with that in more detail later.

I say quite honestly and sincerely that for some time I have had a considerable amount of respect for John Hewson. Therefore, I was both surprised and disappointed at the essentially populist nature of the package which has been presented or, at least, the broad streak of populism which runs through it. I expected better than that from John Hewson.

There is the payroll tax to which I have already referred. Then there is the cheap petrol. Cheap petrol will get cheap cheers, but it sends out an appalling message to the public about the likely future prices of petroleum and will take Australia, again with the United States, right down to the bottom of the OECD table to the extent to which petrol is taxed.

If that were not bad enough, we then have this add on. It appears that farmers will be totally exempt from even a value added tax on petrol. Presently, for very good reasons—justifiably so—farmers receive a total refund of distillate excise because that is, in almost all cases, an input to agricultural production. The amount of petrol used in agricultural production is negligible. I make this very important distinction between petrol used in agricultural production and petrol used by farmers for private motoring, just like everybody else uses petrol. I speak as someone who still maintains a close association with agriculture, who has been a practising wheat and sheep farmer for more than 20 years, when I say that the amount of petrol used in agricultural production is negligible. This is a rort clearly inserted to buy off potential opposition from the National Party.

The next bit of populism contained in the Opposition's document is that we should shift public servants from Canberra to Sydney. Can honourable senators envisage any proposition more stupid than packing off public servants from this city to another city which is already bursting at the seams, the social infrastructure of which cannot cope with the population which is already there? Just as a bonus, can honourable senators imagine a bigger repudiation of the National Party's alleged policy of decentralisation?

Work for the dole—that is always popular with people who, firstly, believe that the unemployed are work shy; and, secondly, have failed to count the additional cost to the Commonwealth Budget of organising and administering work for the dole schemes. Then there is the doublespeak about immigration.

There is no fundamental need for the structural change to the taxation system of the type the Opposition is proposing. The transition costs of the change will be high. The ongoing costs in both the public and private sector of administration will also be significant. Just the public sector cost of the value added tax in the United Kingdom administration amounts to 2 per cent of revenue, which is almost four times the cost of administering Australia's present wholesale sales tax system and about double the cost of administering our income tax system. That does not count the costs in the private sector, which I would expect will be at least equal to the public sector cost. That is not significant. But the high transition costs are really the most dangerous element of this proposal.

The Opposition claimed that the CPI effect of its total package would be 4.4 per cent. It did not take long to find out that it had not factored into that 4.4 per cent figure the 25 per cent increase in excise on tobacco which, in the Opposition's own documents, is put at 0.3 per cent. That takes the CPI effect up to 4.7 per cent. The Opposition has not counted the effect of its health policy changes, which will increase the cost of private health insurance, the road transport element, the Federal Airports Corporation and so on. That 4.4 per cent figure was intrinsically unbelievable. When it has been properly costed by Treasury, I anticipate that the figure will be somewhere between 5 and 6 per cent. But let us be generous and say that it will be only 5 per cent. When there is no good reason—no compelling reason—for making a structural change of this type, why on earth would any sensible opposition or government want to put into the economy an overnight shock, like a 5 per cent increase in the consumer price index?

TALK.START.PARA: —One-off.

—Not necessarily. It was almost a one-off in New Zealand; and it was introduced at the same time that unemployment rocketed up by four or five percentage points. If a Liberal government plans to deal with the inflationary impact of the value added tax by bumping unemployment up 4 or 5 per cent, members of the Opposition should go out and tell the public that that is their intention. If the Opposition does decide to bump unemployment up another 4 or 5 per cent by running an extremely restrictive monetary policy to contain the inflationary impact, because it has already committed itself to not tightening fiscal policy, that will be its choice. But members of the Opposition should go out and tell the public that that is what they are going to do.

PARA.TAB: That happened in New Zealand and the inflationary consequence was more of a pinnacle than a plateau. But, if the Opposition does not do something like that, there is a very real danger that the higher level inflation will be a plateau, not a pinnacle, and will endure for many years. The transition costs will be high—let there be no mistake about that—the ongoing administration costs will be significant and the gains will be small.

The gigantic fraud in this package is the claim that replacing payroll tax with this value added tax will get rid of the alleged damage which payroll tax does to employment and economic activity. In fact, the Opposition is proposing to abolish State payroll taxes and replace them with a Commonwealth payroll tax, via the value added tax, at three times the rate and for about four times, or more than four times, the total revenue. Both payroll taxes and value added taxes are taxes on labour because, with the exception of economic rent, all value added is the direct or indirect consequence of labour. All value, either directly or indirectly, is added by labour once economic rent has been excluded.

I am indebted to Senator Boswell for giving us not a perfect example but a good enough example of the effect of payroll tax. He said, and I take his word for it, that it costs $120 to have a beast boned out in an abattoir. Payroll tax at 6 per cent therefore means that it costs a bit over an extra $7 in payroll tax. The value added tax which the Opposition is proposing to introduce will have the following effect. The proprietor of an abattoir buys a beast for, say, $500. Senator Boswell says that it costs $120 to get it boned out, so the proprietor of the abattoir will insist on getting at least $120 when he sells it to an exporter or to a butcher—that is the value added inside the abattoir on which a 15 per cent tax will be applied. So instead of the tax being $7, as it was in Senator Boswell's example, it will be $18. I am sure that Senator Boswell does not realise, any more than the mugs out there in the small business sector—most of whom, incidentally, are exempt from payroll tax—realise, that a value added tax is a payroll tax under another name which has almost identical employment and general economic effects.

I should add one important qualification to Senator Boswell's example—and I am being fair and objective about this—if the abattoir's proprietor then exports the boned out carcass, no value added tax will be levied. But, if he sells it to a domestic butcher, in this example the value added tax will be $18 as against $7 for payroll tax. The same principle will apply for all commodities which have value added to them within Australia and which are sold within Australia.

Of course, all those who are the final suppliers of a good or a service will try to pass on to consumers the value added tax that they and all other suppliers and processors throughout the production and marketing chain have paid. They will try to pass that tax on to the consumer and in most cases they will succeed, just as payroll tax is passed on to the consumer now whenever the supplying firm has sufficient market power to do so.

I want to make a couple of brief points in the time that I have left. As I said before, income tax collections as a proportion of GDP are not high. It is true that at median or modal levels of income the marginal rates are particularly high, and it is claimed that we have to do something about this. There are two points to be made. Firstly, the evidence as to whether marginal tax rates of that magnitude—that is, around 38c in the dollar—are an effective deterrent to effort or to work is inconclusive. But, even if it were conclusive, it is possible to devise a tax system—revenue neutral—which significantly reduces, I believe to about 30c in the dollar, the marginal tax rate that would apply at that level. I am having some work done on this and I hope to make that public within the next week or two. I am talking about a rate scale which leaves the existing threshold where it is but which, because of rejigging, significantly reduces at or around the modal or median level of income the marginal tax rate from the present 38c to something like 30c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to support Senator Hill's urgency motion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The need to implement the Coalition's Fightback Program offering vision, hope and jobs to the millions of Australians who have suffered under the ruinous years of Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been interesting to listen to the debate this afternoon because the Government has really struggled. First, Senator Button could not give one single, solitary alternative to what this Government was going to do, other than offer Australians more of the same. Quite frankly, Australians do not want more of the same. They now have an unemployment rate of nearly one million in this country. They have had unprecedented high interest rates and an unprecedented high bankruptcy rate. They have had it up to their back teeth. They cannot cope with any more. Yet Senator Button, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, has said, `Sorry, you've got to cop it. You've got to cop it sweet and you've got to take some more of the same'. The Opposition is quite clearly offering an alternative. It is offering hope, it is offering vision and it is offering a reduction in taxation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Maguire's contribution worried me because he kept saying that he wanted things like food exempt; that he wanted to make sure that essential items were exempt. I would have thought that Senator Maguire would know better—that exemption of essential items like that really would benefit the wealthy more than the poor. It is the wealthy who use more services, not the poor, and it is the wealthy who go to restaurants more often than the poor. In pushing this silly, inane, inaccurate exempt line, Senator Maguire wants to make sure that the people who need the tax reductions do not get them. He wants to make sure that the people on welfare, the low income earners, will be worse off than they are today—if that is at all possible.

Senator Maguire wants to make sure that our ability to compensate anybody in the low income areas is reduced. That is absolutely scandalous. He wants to make sure that there are less tax cuts and that there is less incentive for people to work. Quite frankly, I am tired of hearing people saying, `It is not worth my time working overtime'. We are going to make it worth people's time not only to work overtime but also to work longer hours generally because they will reap the benefits.

We are reducing the levels of taxation and we are making sure that the tax threshold will be raised from $5,400 to $7,000, with a 16.2 per cent marginal rate applying below $20,700 in place of the current 20 per cent rate. A person earning $10,000, who currently pays $920 annually in tax, would pay $486 in tax. That happens to be a 47 per cent reduction in income tax.

Of course, this Government has tried to say that we will give higher tax breaks to those people on higher incomes than to those on lower incomes. That is a complete and utter lie—no more, no less. Sure, people on higher incomes will get more dollar value; but people on lower incomes—on $7,000 per year, for example—will get a 100 per cent tax reduction. People on higher incomes will get a 13, 14, 15 per cent or maybe even up to a 23 per cent reduction; but people on low incomes will get a significantly higher tax reduction.

Senator Walsh's contribution was interesting, to say the least, considering that Senator Walsh—himself a former Minister for Finance—has been a huge advocate of the introduction of a goods and services tax. He now says that it really does not work. But only the other night—I think it was Monday night, if my memory serves me well—he appeared on national television saying that he had been an advocate of it and that, yes, it can work. But he said that things like cheap petrol will bring cheap cheers, particularly from farmers.

I cannot understand why Senator Walsh, as a farmer, hates farmers as much as he does. Quite clearly, farmers will benefit from the abolition of the petroleum excise. There is no question about that. An enormous amount of fuel is used in the production process on farms, an enormous amount of fuel is used in getting stock backwards and forwards from farms, and a huge quantity of fuel is used in getting products from point A to point B. That is why people in the bush pay more for their various commodities. How dare he talk about rural and remote Australia not benefiting from an abolition of excise. They simply will; there is no question about that.

People in the north-west of Western Australia, for example, have to pay the huge costs of transportation on top of every product they buy. That puts a significant cost onto products. When the fuel excise is abolished, 26c per litre will come off the cost of transportation of goods to places in remote and rural Australia.

Senator Walsh said there was no compelling reason for changes of this kind. We have nearly one million people unemployed in this country. If that is not sufficient cause for compelling reasons for change now, there never will be. We must ensure that the aged are looked after and that they have opportunities. I know from personal experience how superannuants have their incomes diminished year in year out by the huge rate of inflation and huge cost burdens that are being imposed on those types of people. Under this Government, they are forced to pay extra for their private health insurance because they know that if they do not pay that private health insurance they will be consigned to the waiting lists. They will not be able to get the doctor, hospital and treatment of their choice at the time of their choice unless they make that additional payment for private health insurance.

We will make sure they do have that type of access; not only to public hospitals but also to private hospitals. Of course, we will make sure that bulkbilling is retained for pensioners, health care cardholders and the disabled so they simply will not be disadvantaged. Once again, it is just not true for this Government to say that people will be disadvantaged under a health policy which the Government and its supporters have largely advocated.

Even the Government's supporters have come out this week and said that it was about time that people were taken back into the private health insurance system when many of them can afford to pay private health insurance but choose not to because they know that somewhere along the line they might get some medical attention. The problem is that many Australians have not been able to get the medical attention when they have needed it, with their choice of timing, doctor and hospital. It is about time that we made that opportunity available for all Australians.

As I said before, it is also important and significant that rural and remote Australia will benefit largely from this as well. We are making sure that the zone allowance for remote Australia, for example, is increased by 25 per cent. That, too, is significant for these people. That is a huge increase in the allowance for people living in places such as Nullagine in Western Australia. Of course, it is a substantial allowance for people in areas such as the Pilbara and the Kimberley, who have suffered for so long under this Government. There has not been one increase in the zone allowance in the eight or nine years of misery under this Government. The costs have gone up and up with not 1c of compensation. For the first time, there will be compensation.

Senator Walsh made the comment that the abolition of payroll tax would not solve anything. It is a shame that none of his colleagues in the States agree with that sentiment. None of the business people agree with that sentiment either. Surely, it is up to us to make sure that there are incentives for people to get out there and employ more people without all of these taxes on employment—not only payroll tax but also the training guarantee levy. By bringing in this tax and forcing business to pay yet another tax on employment, this Government in many cases has reduced the amount of dollars being spent on training. But does it care? No, it is just another tax.

It is interesting to think that we are one week down the track and the Government has not been able to find one alternative to a very comprehensive package which is designed to pull Australia up by its bootstraps and give all Australians a fair go and something to look forward to in this great country.

That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important report because it covers an important organisation, the Australian National Gallery. PARA.TAB: As we have mentioned in this place before, no-one is being sued and no recompense can be sought from anyone involved in what was clearly a mistake and a mess-up. I stress that I have the highest regard for both the board and the Director of the Gallery. The annual report skirts around the subject of the actual cost that the taxpayers are having to face because of this negligence, error or mistake by a builder, architect or someone. It is disappointing that the finger is not pointed at whoever made the disastrous mistake.

The Gallery has suffered not only the normal downturn that it would expect in a recession with respect to the number of people attending, but the closure of parts of the Gallery and its inability to run what it describes as a `blockbuster' exhibition in the past 12 months has significantly affected its program. SPEECH.PARA: In moving the motion, I wish to address a few remarks to the report of the National Plantations Advisory Committee entitled Integrating forestry and farming: commercial wood production on cleared agricultural land. I was very pleased to read this report. I was especially pleased with the language used in the first part of the report; I found the executive summary most interesting indeed. This is a matter which has been of some personal interest for many years since the advantages of integrated forestry and farming were first brought to my attention when I was lucky enough to visit a property south-east of Hobart—a property owned by the Downie family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Bruce Downie.

—Senator Calvert, quite correctly, has made sure that I identified the correct Downie family because there are a lot of them—many of them successful farmers in Tasmania. However, this farm demonstrates well the advantages which accrue from successfully integrating farming and timber production. In the report we have a furthering of that argument.

PARA.TAB: The report also highlights some of the disincentives and the things which preclude further expansion of these sorts of enterprises. We are told in the very first paragraph of the report that the Government's objective of fostering a plantation resource on cleared agricultural land is attainable provided that several things occur: for example, provided that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . industrial processing companies are prepared to obtain a significant proportion of their wood from farmers, as well as their own or State resources.

Of course, that is the key to a lot of successful enterprises. If we are able to ensure before we engage in producing a product that it has a market or can be sold, then it is a heck of a lot easier to have a successful enterprise. The key to this enterprise is that provided the production of integrated farming and tree production can be guaranteed an end market then, of course, it is more likely that such an enterprise will succeed.

PARA.TAB: However, that is not the only matter that needs to be addressed. We are told further in the report that there are certain taxation disincentives that need to be removed and that modest incentives are needed to encourage investors. This is apparent in many areas, but I would have thought that this would be something that the Government could follow up fairly easily and quickly. We are also told that there are impediments. Those impediments are mentioned: for example, distortions in the pricing system for wood which should be reduced. This is a matter which has often been denied, yet here we have in black and white an acknowledgment that those distortions do exist and that they should certainly be addressed immediately.

I must say that I find it very easy to agree with all the dot points under the heading `Environmental protection' in the executive summary on page ix of the report. I would like to emphasise the second dot point, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: invasion of publicly owned native forest by exotic species needs to be monitored. . .

We know that the species pinus radiata is a particularly invasive and aggressive seeder. There are even some ornamental species such as rhododendrons and cotoneasters which are now a problem in our native forests. Therefore, care needs to be taken, regardless of whether we are talking about ornamental gardens or integrating farming and forestry. Apart from the care, I am glad to see that this report encourages the activity to be undertaken. The many advantages which could be derived from the report are only in our national interest. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to say a few words about the report of the National Plantations Advisory Committee entitled Integrating forestry and farming: commercial wood production on cleared agricultural land. I believe that this a very positive report. It contains a number of recommendations and I await with interest the Government's response as to whether it does anything about those recommendations. I am advised that the Committee met some 12 times over seven months and undertook extensive investigations of plantations in Australia and overseas. The Chairman of the Committee has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee commissioned a number of far reaching studies into aspects of plantation development on cleared agricultural land such as financial mechanisms and structural impediments, and environmental and management constraints and farm planning and community involvement.
The Chairman continued:

..the Government's objective of fostering a plantation resource on cleared agricultural land is achievable if Governments at all levels implement new policy measures to facilitate plantation development and if there is a commitment from industry to obtain a significant proportion of wood from farmers as well as from their own and State resources.
The Chairman also stated:

I am pleased to say that the Committee reached consensus on all but one recommendation, the exception being that the National Farmers Federation is unable to support the recommendation which proposes a rebate for approved expenditures on plantation establishment and maintenance additional to the 100 per cent deductibility provision. The Federation does however recognise the support of all the other Committee members for this recommendation.

The report, of course, brought together a variety of individuals and organisations. That basically is the only recommendation on which there was not general agreement. This is one of the more positive approaches from what I regard as a negative Government.

PARA.TAB: The Committee, in an attempt to examine dispassionately the viability of plantation forestry and to ensure future timber resources and supplies, has come out with a report that recognises the important role that farmers play and will play in future years in the supply of timber. It recognises the present impediments to investment in timber and suggests that the present taxation disincentives be removed and some incentives put in place. It recognises that environmental protection is important and proposes a code of plantation practice and monitoring of invasion of native forests by exotic species. It suggests a public awareness educational program, to which I say hear, hear! It also recommends an acceleration of forestry research and development.

Some time ago I visited the CSIRO Division of Forestry at Yarralumla and was astounded at the work being undertaken there and the enthusiasm the staff had for the work at hand. So much work is still to be done, so much knowledge still to be gained and so little money is available for it. Until we get a decent new attitude in Australia and get incentives into everything by having a vision such as our Fightback campaign whereby we give incentives to people through better tax structures and better attitudes to doing things, we will not get done a lot of the things which are desperately needed to be done.

The report suggests that the Committee is convinced that the Government's objective of fostering a farm-based plantations resource is attainable, providing those disincentives are removed and the incentives are such that farmers are encouraged to retain control of their land and there is a prospect of markets for their products in the long run. I hope that the Government looks very seriously at this report and will not do what it has done with a lot of other reports and just shelve it. I hope it does something that will really help in integrating forestry and farming so that we have a good commercial wood production on cleared agricultural land.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 13 of 1991-92, entitled Efficiency Audit—Evaluation and preparation of the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's efficiency report No. 13 of 1991-92 on the evaluation and preparation of the Budget is important. It calls for departments and agencies to improve the provision of evaluation of program performance as a basic requirement in their Budget proposal documentation. Certainly that is a call by the National Audit Office that I would strongly endorse.

PARA.TAB: The report is damning so far as its assessment of the Government's evaluation of its program performance in the preparation of the Budget is concerned. Since 1987 when the Government developed its strategy of performance evaluation—a strategy that the Opposition agrees with as a general proposition—there has been, according to the report before us now, only a marginal improvement in general evaluation.

Even when evaluation studies may have been carried out they were not always available on time for consideration of the Budget. Often they would merely state that evaluation would be undertaken but without any detailed information on the appropriate methods of evaluation.

The report deals with various government departments. It is particularly critical of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It says that PMC needed `to be more effective in supporting Department of Finance efforts to upgrade the level of performance information provided by agencies'.

As the Senate is aware, recent Senate Estimates committee hearings revealed just how little the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet appears to understand the purposes of performance evaluation. Its performance indicator statements in the 1991-92 Budget Papers lacked virtually any substance. They were full of warm, inner glow rhetoric about social justice and the like but they contained very few useful indicators to enable the Parliament to review the Department's performance.

It is not just the printed Budget Papers which provide opportunity for evaluation of program performance. The whole purpose of our Senate Estimates committee procedures is to examine government expenditure proposals contained within the Budget and to comment on these in the light of past program performance.

Yet at the Senate Estimates hearings the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet officers were muzzled by the Minister present, who as I recall was Senator Button, from providing any indication of the nature of their advice to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on interest rates or any information about the economic modelling unit that they admitted they were developing within that Department.

Members of the Opposition raised with the officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet just why it was that they needed to develop economic models at all when this new model is being put into Treasury to try to model the coalition's proposed goods and services tax and related proposals, and when there are already very sophisticated modelling devices within Treasury and certain other departments.

To have, to use the words of the officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the development of a `rudimentary economic modelling system' within that Department seemed to smack yet again of the duplication and overlap that have occurred to a very considerable degree in many departments, but particularly in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet under this Government.

As a consequence of all of that and particularly the muzzling that occurred during the Senate Estimates committee hearings, the Parliament and the Australian taxpayers have no way of judging whether that money, which is their money, has been well spent. That has major implications for the accountability of the Government in its use of taxpayers' funds.

I also endorse the Audit Office's recognition of the useful role that the Cabinet Office can play in improving the quality of program performance information by drawing on Department of Finance specialist knowledge. Despite growth in the Cabinet Office over the last several years, it appears to be failing, along with the Department of Finance, in terms of the coordination of performance evaluation.

The report and information that we have gleaned from Senate Estimates hearings in recent times leads me to the view that the Government has so far refused to acknowledge that, without the provision of forward revenue estimates as part of overall Budget documentation alongside the forward expenditure estimates, it is impossible to evaluate the Government's budgetary situation in any future years. The idea of having Forward Estimates in terms of expenditure, which this Government does, loses a lot of its point if there is not a revenue Forward Estimates basis against which to judge it. Both the New South Wales and Tasmanian State governments have recently adopted the practice of having both forward estimates of expenditure and forward estimates of revenue in their budgets. It is something that the Commonwealth also ought to be looking at.

It is not as if the Government does not already calculate forward revenue estimates. The Treasury does for its budgeting purposes but it will not publish them. The Department of Finance admitted during our Estimates hearings that it also has a go at estimating forward revenues. We got a very inconclusive and unsatisfactory answer from Department of Finance officers and Department of the Treasury officers in the Estimates hearings as to why the Department of Finance had to try to second guess the Treasury in building up forward revenue estimates. That is something that I also believe needs to be looked at. They are some points that emerge from the Auditor-General's Report No. 13. In the time available, and given that we are losing altitude a little with our program, I will reserve any further comments for another occasion.

I draw to the Senate's attention the importance of this report and the importance of an improvement of evaluation techniques within the public financing systems of government. The Government spends vast amounts of money on programs, particularly in the areas of policy advising where it is very difficult—and I do not underestimate the difficulty—to get a proper technique whereby one can evaluate whether the work being undertaken by those advisory bodies is good value for money. Indeed, we can try to evaluate the performance of Treasury over the last few years and accept that the Treasury has been the main adviser to government. We can also look at the fact that we have almost a million people unemployed and at least another half a million people underemployed. There has also been a dramatic fall in private investment, private consumption and gross domestic product and a major blow-out in our foreign debt and current account. If that is the outcome of the programs of policy advice by departments such as the Treasury, one would have to express the gravest concern about those performances.

I return to the essential problem: how does one evaluate programs within government agencies and departments, particularly where they are of other than a service delivery nature and the measurement problem is much easier and very different? The work that has been done by the Department of Finance in recent years in improving evaluation techniques and evaluation processes is to be commended. The report of the Audit Office is also to be commended in that context because it really points to the fact that there is still a long way to go before we can be satisfied that those techniques and new arrangements are satisfactory. In that context and in that sense, the report bears very careful scrutiny by us all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
