TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch, I was talking to the second reading of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill. I had reached the point where I was talking about the deficiencies of Montreal Amendment Protocols Nos. 3 and 4, which the Government will sign as a consequence of the passage of this Bill. I was pointing out that, even though this

SPEECH.PARA: is a new protocol, it has been around for 16 years. I was saying that there were some major deficiencies with the Montreal Protocols that would be signed for Australia.

PARA.TAB: In outlining their faults, I pointed out the futility of this legislation because at the end of the day it leaves Australia worse off than it is at present. Firstly, one of the disabilities with the Montreal Protocols was that they had an unbreakable liability. There was a ceiling for compensation which could not be exceeded, irrespective of the fault of the carrier. I said that there was no opportunity for carriers to lift their liability on their own behalf as they can under the existing protocols. Indeed, there is no mechanism for the Montreal Protocols to be altered in any way, because they are inflexible.

I moved to the point that the figure for compensation was far too low. The figure of 100,000 special drawing rights from the International Monetary Fund that has been adopted by the Government works out at between $170,000 and $180,000. I am astonished that the Government should value human life as cheaply as that. By way of illustration—I do not wish to canvass the field of damages within Australia today—in the recent past we have had damages of $3m awarded to a quadriplegic as a consequence of an accident. It is not at all uncommon in cases of injuries to limbs or joints to have compensation payments of many hundreds of thousands of dollars awarded.

The figure of $170,000 to $180,000, the ceiling for the compensation which applies in Montreal Protocol No. 3, is grossly out of line with contemporary Australian damages that can be awarded. It is very interesting to note that, had the protocol been accepted by the airline carriers of the world in 1975, as of right we would have had two review points within that protocol, at a five-year and a 10-year period. On each occasion the SDRs would have been increased by $12,500. Clearly, the intention of the people who drew up the Montreal Protocol in 1971 was to review the protocol and to issue a fresh one at some time, probably 15 years, after it was drawn up. It would depend on whether the drawing up date is taken to be 1971 or 1975. If we take the 1975 figure, 16 years have elapsed. The compensation provisions are, therefore, very clearly dated.

One of the things that the Government has not done is come up with some supplementary compensatory Act to allow Australian international carriers to add to the benefits specified in the Montreal Protocol. That is the only way in which benefits can be increased under this protocol. If the United States ever signs the protocol—as I said earlier, that is very much in doubt—it will have in place on the legislative books a supplementary compensatory Act providing for higher benefits, preceding the signature. The Government here is very wrong to propose this Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1991 to the Parliament and to sign the protocols without having put on our statute books supplementary compensatory legislation. At the end of the day I think it is very unlikely that Montreal Protocol No. 3 and Montreal Protocol No. 4 will ever be accepted by the world airlines collectively. The airlines have precisely the same objections to it as I have.

There is one interesting point that I want to comment on. By consigning this Bill into legislation, the Government will actually reduce the benefits that are available today for an Australian passenger or for a passenger flying on an Australian international airline. If the Warsaw Convention and The Hague Protocol are applied under the existing Australian Act which we are amending today, and the gold standard conversion is taken, the liability of the carrier is at least $250,000; but, when this legislation comes in, the compensation amount will be linked to 100,000 statutory units of the IMF, which is $170,000 to $180,000, as I said earlier.

I cannot emphasise strongly enough the need to have adequate market compensation in this field. If we look back to 1929 when aviation was in its infancy and when the first Warsaw Convention, which is still in place, was applied, we will see that the value then of the gold conversion was $US10,000. If we were to convert that 1929 value of $US10,000 into today's currency figures, we would find it was considerably more than the $170,000 to $180,000 that applies at the moment.

In effect, we are turning back the clock because Australians will be disadvantaged. Apart from that, 30 per cent of the travellers coming into and going out of this country will still continue to be covered by the original Warsaw Convention and the modified Warsaw Convention, The Hague Protocol. That means that in most cases those travellers will have higher benefits than a passenger suing under the Montreal Protocol No. 3 that we are proposing to sign.

Clearly, we do need to try for a new international agreement. The present situation is not satisfactory. We do need some clear and simple convention. We should not be working with a system that goes back 61 years to the dawn of aviation—not that there are not some very good and very relevant points in the original Warsaw Convention. I believe a new agreement should have strict liability in it. It should have regular review periods and it should be flexible enough to allow carriers to increase the ceiling if they choose to do so. None of those characteristics is in the amended Montreal Protocol No. 3 or Montreal Protocol No. 4.

Finally, the tragedy of the present situation is that by passing the Bill and having Australia become a signatory to Montreal Additional Protocol No. 3 and Montreal Protocol No. 4, we will have to remove ourselves from the earlier Warsaw Convention and The Hague Protocol. At the end of the day there is simply no guarantee that the United States will sign. If the United States does not sign, the other airlines of the world, as a bloc, will not pick it up and we will end up with the worst of all worlds. It is with the greatest of reluctance that we will allow this Bill to pass. We do so on an undertaking from the Government that it will, as a matter of great urgency, move to have some supplementary compensatory Act passed in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Government has, indeed, given that undertaking very clearly. It was always intending to do that. As Senator MacGibbon would know, the United States is proceeding along similar lines in working on a supplementary package which is specifically provided for under the Montreal Protocol. I guess in that sense—I think that Senator MacGibbon clarified this—that it is strictly technically correct to say that the Montreal Protocol sets absolute limits that cannot be broken. The protocol quite clearly provides for a supplementary scheme providing that it is arranged in the way in which the United States is proceeding to do it; that is, that it act as an insurance supplementary scheme with levies applied for that purpose.

PARA.TAB: I wish just to cover a number of the points that Senator MacGibbon has made. I think Senator MacGibbon has severely understated the difficulties of proceeding to break the limits that are set by the Warsaw Convention as amended at The Hague. The evidence is stark and easily available to demonstrate just how difficult that is, particularly for an individual. The test that has to be applied in the case of both—

TALK.START.PARA: —The facility is there.

—As is often said, the law, like the Ritz Hotel, is open to all: one can stay there provided one can afford the tariff. It is a very high test, and it goes beyond a test of simple negligence. It is a very tough test indeed.

PARA.TAB: As Senator MacGibbon knows, the debate about this trade-off between common law actions and a scheme such as that in the Montreal Protocol applies to all areas of compensation—motor vehicle accidents and all the rest of it. It is a very important and lively debate which I have engaged in many times, the trade-offs being particularly the value of a no-fault scheme where, in order to get rapid and inexpensive redress, the person does not have to establish fault on the part of the driver, or in this case the airline.

In order to break those limits, by taking action for damages, a very high standard of fault is required. In the case of the Warsaw Convention, a claimant has to prove wilful misconduct. In the case of the Warsaw Convention as amended by The Hague Protocol, a claimant has to prove either the intention to cause damage—and Senator MacGibbon would know full well just how difficult it is to establish intent in a court—or recklessness with knowledge that damage would probably result from that recklessness. That is an extremely severe test to apply to a civil action and it is a much higher test than simple negligence.

To give an example to the Senate as to just how difficult, prolonged and expensive it is to establish that test, claims in relation to the infamous flight 007 disaster and the Erebus disaster in New Zealand are still not settled. They are still being litigated years after the event. In the case of the Erebus disaster, 12 years have now elapsed and those claims have still not been settled. So it is not easy to get results by taking this course of action.

To refer to a very substantive point that Senator MacGibbon made at the beginning of his contribution to the debate, the Opposition has canvassed a couple of options. One is to simply withdraw the Bill and the other is to amend it. As Senator MacGibbon knows, we have acceded to the Opposition's wishes and have agreed to amend the Bill in line with the concerns the Opposition has raised rather than withdraw the Bill. We make no apology for proceeding with the Bill.

It is the clear intention of Australia to become party to the Montreal Protocols. Indeed, the International Civil Aviation Organisation, ICAO, has formally and officially and very loudly called for all member states to become signatories to this convention, and I think for good reason. It does offer very significant benefits to people who are aggrieved, providing that—and I concede this point—it is supported by some sort of supplementary scheme that would allow the limits to be raised in a manner which does not force upon the person concerned the prospect of years and, perhaps in some cases, decades of painful and expensive litigation.

In the second reading speech to the Senate, I explained that the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill does three things: it amends the principal Act to enable Australian ratification of Montreal Protocols 3 and 4; it applies with immediate effect increased liability limits of 100,000 SDR, that is, approximately $A180,000 for passenger death and injury, to Australia's international airlines; and it converts the Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol Poincare gold franc liability limits to SDRs.

PARA.TAB: The Government has received representations, as I have mentioned, concerning the Bill as originally drafted. Concerns about the Bill have focused on a number of issues, in particular, the unacceptably low liability limits, particularly when compared with non-aircraft civil accident actions, and the lack of standardisation of coverage for all passengers. The Government acknowledges and indeed shares these concerns. However, many of the concerns are criticisms of the international carriers liability regime that are actually embodied in the Warsaw Convention and that Convention as amended by The Hague Protocol.

For Australia to legislate to increase and standardise the liability limits applicable to all passengers travelling to, from and within Australia would effectively require Australia's withdrawal from the international carriers liability regime. Whilst it is undeniable that there are difficulties with the regime, particularly in regard to the liability limits, as Senator MacGibbon has already mentioned, the Government remains committed to the view that the complex issue of liability of international air carriers should continue to be addressed in the multi-lateral context rather than on a piecemeal basis with each country enacting its own laws on the subject.

For all of its shortcomings, the international regime does contain very real benefits to the international passenger, such as not having to prove fault on the part of the airline, the speed of payment of compensation, and the certainty of jurisdiction in which the cases can be heard. The Government, therefore, does not consider, as I have said before, that withdrawal from the Warsaw Convention system would be an option that is realistically available to us. Having said this, however, I must say that the Government acknowledges the major criticisms that are directed to the Bill.

If passed, the Bill would leave 30 per cent of passengers travelling to and from Australia significantly worse off, as Senator MacGibbon has said, than they currently are. In particular, those provisions of the Bill which convert the Warsaw and Hague gold franc limits to SDRs in effect limit the maximum entitlement of passengers for death or injury to $28,000 or less. Moreover, it has been argued in some quarters that this would potentially deprive passengers of substantially higher payouts if a court were to convert the gold franc limits using the market price of gold.

Accordingly, the amendments which I have moved on behalf of the Government will remove those provisions which purport to fix the Warsaw and Hague liability limits by reference to SDRs. The amendments also remove those provisions which limit the liability of Australia's international carriers to 100,000 SDRs. Qantas will of course continue to apply this limit on a voluntary basis and we will continue to encourage foreign airlines to adopt higher voluntary limits.

In moving the amendments, the Government wishes to emphasis that it is preserving the status quo. The Government understands that in the short term the existing uncertainty is the quantum of limits under the Warsaw Convention and that convention as amended by The Hague Protocol will persist. However, the Government does not wish to deny passengers any rights or opportunities which they currently may enjoy before the courts.

The Bill in its amended form will enable Australia to ratify the Montreal Protocols, as called upon to do so by ICAO, which the Government is confident will ultimately become the mainstay of the international carriers liability regime. This would result in a standard 100,000 SDR limit applying to all international passengers.

If the Montreal Protocols receive the required number of ratifications and enter into force internationally before Australia is legislatively prepared to ratify the protocols, the carriers liability for carriage between Australia and countries which are party to the Montreal Protocols could become unlimited. As a result, passengers would have to prove fault on the part of the airlines. They may not be able to have a case heard in Australia and compensation, if any, could be a long time coming.

The Government remains very concerned about the low limits placed on the liability of international carriers, even by the Montreal Protocols. One hundred thousand SDRs, which as I have said before is about $A180,000, for passenger death and injury is still low when compared with payouts in non-aircraft civil accident actions.

Accordingly, I reiterate in conclusion the commitment the Government has given to examine the feasibility of a supplementary compensation scheme which will enable passengers speedy and certain access to realistic levels of compensation. My colleague the Acting Attorney-General, Senator Tate, supports the immediate commencement of an examination of such a scheme. I also say, in fairness, that I have received representations previously from the Acting Attorney-General on the same issue. However, as honourable senators would recognise from the explanatory memorandum and the supplementary explanatory memorandum, the issues are complex, as Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, and the implications of a supplementary scheme will have to be carefully assessed, but we commit ourselves to carry out that examination promptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that explanation. In light of what he has said, a couple of points come to mind. I accept his assurance that the Government will proceed with the supplementary compensation scheme. I presume that the Government will legislate for that prior to signing the Montreal Protocols; otherwise I do not see how Qantas can maintain its present higher level under the Hague-Warsaw convention, because that will be null and void. The Government will have to abrogate that agreement in light of signing the Montreal one. That is the first point. My second point is that I would assume that in the supplementary compensation scheme something would be done about property damage in relation to baggage or cargo, because the Montreal convention, as well as having a ridiculously low level of $180,000 for loss of a life, has a limit of $28 per kilo on baggage or freight on an aircraft. That is also quite absurd from a compensation point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which the coalition will not be opposing. The Bill implements some of the Government's Budget decisions but there are also important non-Budget changes. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) pointed out in his second reading speech in the other place, a number of Budget decisions are being enacted by changes to delegated legislation or by changes in administrative arrangements.

PARA.TAB: One Budget amendment in this Bill, which will be of great interest to many veterans, is the indexation of the earnings credit. At the moment earnings credit is fixed at $1,000. This Bill amends the Veterans' Entitlements Act so that the earnings credit maximum is indexed to reflect changes in the consumer price index. The coalition welcomes this measure, as I am sure many veterans will. The amendment takes effect from the start of the next financial year.

It is an important step along the path of encouraging veterans to earn additional income to supplement their pension where they can and wish to. As an aside, I might mention that in the coalition's recently released Fightback package a specific undertaking was given for an ongoing review by a coalition government of the income and assets test limits applying to pensions, including service pensions, so as to encourage veterans to supplement their pensions without penalty—and I stress `without penalty'.

In the same package, the coalition also set out details of our proposed deferred pension plan. Under that plan veterans who wished to remain in the work force beyond age 60 and qualified for the service pension and wanted to defer it would receive a bigger pension as a result. For example, a 60-year-old service pensioner who deferred his pension for two years would receive a pension increase of 16 per cent in the fortnightly pension.

The other significant amendments contained in this Bill and pertaining to the Budget concern changes to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Government is extending patient contributions for pharmaceuticals to holders of special treatment entitlement cards and personal treatment entitlement cards. Holders of these cards receive pharmaceuticals under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The patient contribution itself, which is to be $2.60 per prescription item and indexed according to the CPI, is introduced via an instrument signed by the Minister and which has already been tabled. Importantly, amendments contained in this legislation provide for the payment of a pharmaceutical allowance to veterans to compensate them for the patient contribution. The pharmaceutical allowance is to be paid at the rate of $5.20 per fortnight and will also be indexed to the CPI.

In accepting this measure, the coalition has been very concerned to ensure that the Government properly protects chronic users of medication. This is particularly important given that one might expect the disability veteran population to be greater users of medication than those currently obtaining pharmaceuticals under the PBS. One important measure in this regard is the safety net which comes into play after more than 52 prescriptions have been used. After this point all prescriptions are free. The safety net limit has the effect of ensuring that veterans, over the course of 12 months, are not out of pocket. Indeed, if veterans use fewer than 52 prescriptions over the course of 12 months they will be financially better off.

For heavy users of medication, that is, those veterans who may use a number of prescriptions per week, an advance pharmaceutical allowance will be made available. The Government has met coalition concerns that these veterans should have easy access to advance pharmaceutical allowance. As from 1 January 1992 all veterans and war widows, not just STEC and PTEC holders, will no longer have to satisfy an assets test to qualify for the advance allowance.

In addition, by this legislation war widows and disability pensioners are exempted from the income test for the advance allowance. In this sense, veterans' access to an advance seems to be much better than that for general pensioners covered under the PBS. I have received, as I know a number of other honourable senators have, a great deal of correspondence from veterans on the issue of the patient contribution. Concern has been expressed that extension of a patient contribution to disability pensioners undermines the concept of assistance for veterans being provided on the basis of compensation rather than welfare.

The coalition is very aware of this important distinction. In the time that I have been the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs there have been many issues on which the coalition has taken the Government to task for its lack of comprehension of the special standing of veterans. Earlier this year, for instance, it was the coalition, with the support of the Australian Democrats, which overthrew the misguided introduction of entry fees at the Australian War Memorial.

The result of this has been that the War Memorial has had to think more carefully about other means of raising revenue to enhance its activities. I note that one of the recommendations in a recent union review of staffing at the Memorial is to look once again at the introduction of entry fees. I understand that the report is presently in the hands of the Memorial's management group for response. I say now that the Memorial would be very foolish to again suggest the introduction of entry fees, and that such a suggestion will be opposed on every occasion by the coalition. If the Government is not funding the War Memorial appropriately, as has been suggested recently by the Council Chairman, then it is the Government of Australia which must be held accountable by the people of Australia.

Late last year the Government attempted to introduce a new guide to the assessment of rates of veterans pensions which would have dramatically reduced the ability of veterans to successfully appeal for an increase in disability pension. The coalition succeeded then in having the new guide disallowed in the Senate. This rejection by the Parliament has meant that the Department has had to go away and work more closely with the ex-service community to ensure that a more equitable third edition of the guide is produced. I understand, both from the ex-service community and the Department, that good progress is being made and that a new guide may be tabled early in the next session of parliament.

Integration legislation introduced by the Government, which is shortly to be debated by the Senate, is being opposed by the coalition. It has been introduced in the absence of detailed information on the nature of negotiations with the States, in the absence of detailed information on the cost implications of the so-called private patient scheme, and in the face of the genuinely held fears of the ex-service community, which has many unresolved concerns with the integration process. So I think it should be clear to the veterans of Australia that, even in opposition, the coalition has done a great deal to ensure that the special standing of veterans is properly recognised and that their hard-won rights and entitlements are not easily given away.

The coalition has considered very carefully the implications of the patient contribution associated with this Bill. The rationale for a patient contribution is centred on the need to curb overprescribing and oversupply of medication and to encourage sensible drug use throughout the community. In this sense, I think it is important that the soundly based concern of the effect of overuse and oversupply on veterans health be recognised.

Although it is too early to make any definitive judgments, initial evidence from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services indicates that there has been a significant reduction in the number of pharmaceuticals dispensed for pensioners, including service pensioners and war widows, as a consequence of legislation which was introduced following last year's Budget. The Government has predicted a long term reduction of around 15 per cent and the evidence to date, although by no means conclusive, at least conforms with this prediction.

From the coalition's point of view, this can only mean better and more efficient health care for veterans, and that is something we should all support. As I indicated at the start of my speech, many of the changes arising from this year's Budget are being introduced by delegated legislation or revised administrative arrangements. Two of these changes—the provision of emergency short term home relief for veterans and war widows from January next year and the development of a hostel development scheme—are important and are welcomed by the Opposition. These changes have flowed directly from the report by Professor Gary Andrews on his consultancy on long term care for veterans and war widows. The Government did not offer the coalition a copy of this important report and it has obtained it only in recent days. We are considering the substance of the report carefully.

Another Budget change being implemented by delegated legislation is the extension from 1 December of repatriation treatment benefits to Australian merchant mariners of World War I and World War II. While the coalition welcomes some progress on this front, given that the McGirr report has been in the hands of the Minister since October 1989, I am sure that these same mariners will be disappointed that the Government has not fully embraced the McGirr report and given Australian merchant mariners the same legislative standing as veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

Of course, there were a number of important issues in the ex-service community which the Government failed to address in the last Budget. I want to draw particular attention to one of these: the 50,000 war widows who are subject to discrimination in comparison with civilian widows. When this issue was raised in the Estimates Committee hearings in April earlier this year, the veteran community was led to believe that it could expect some sort of response to this situation in this year's Budget. Needless to say, for the 50,000 war widows who continue to be the subject of this discrimination, no action was taken. According to the Government, discussions are still continuing at a ministerial level, with a number of options being considered.

Given that any steps taken to redress this situation may involve considerable expenditure, it is reasonable to expect that any decision will have to occur in a Budget context. Sadly for the affected war widows, this means a wait of at least another nine months. Given that the median age of war widows is around 72 years, any decision taken nine months from now by this Government will, for some, be too little, too late.

I now want to move to the non-budgetary features of this Bill. The most significant of these are changes to operational areas. The passing of the Veterans' Entitlements Act in 1986 saw the consolidation of a great many pieces of veterans legislation into one Act. As part of this consolidation, operational areas were gathered together from the various disparate acts and regulations. Thus schedule 2 of the VEA sets out, for pension purposes, the various operational areas in which defence personnel have served.

For reasons which to this day are not clear, the drafting of the VEA in 1986 had a number of operational areas covered by the blanket dates of 31 July 1962 up to and including 11 January 1973. For some areas, this was clearly not appropriate but, given that a veteran had to be deemed to have been allotted for service in an operational area rather than merely being in an operational area before qualifying for the service pension, the dates were less important. Of course, two important cases—the Doessel and Davis cases—saw the Federal Court interpret `allotted for duty' in such a way that the dates in which an area was truly operational have now become very much more important. Consequently, the Government, in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, moved amendments which modified the operational areas for Borneo, item 6, and Malaysia, item 7.

In the Bill before us now, further modifications are being sought. Item 5, which relates to the Malayan conflict, is being wound back from the period 31 July 1962 to 11 January 1973 inclusive, to the period 28 May 1963 to 19 April 1967 inclusive. Item 7, relating to the Malaysian conflict, is being amended again. I can only assume that the Department got it wrong last year, presumably acting on advice from Defence. The starting date for Malaysia is being changed from 7 July 1965 to 17 August 1964.

The changing of these dates has caused some concern to the coalition and to the ex-service community. On the face of it, they could very easily be read as somehow taking away veterans' entitlements. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in its Alert Digest No. 19 of 1991, indicated to the Minister that it would appreciate further information on the intention and effect of the proposed amendments. The Committee is concerned, as I am, that a veteran who does not put in a claim until after 8 November and can show that he was in a legitimate operational area during a period outside the prescribed dates will not be eligible for repatriation benefits.

The Department has indicated to me that, to the best of its knowledge, the dates are accurate and will not prevent veterans access to benefits that are rightfully due to them. I have had a number of people in the ex-service community provide me with instances where they thought the operational areas were not appropriate. I have raised these matters with the Department and on each occasion it has been able to reconcile them satisfactorily, either to the dates as amended or to other items in the schedule.

While the Opposition has the Department's assurances on this matter, I think it is vital that the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that should any cases emerge which clearly show the operational dates to be inappropriate, then the Government will move to ensure that such veterans are properly recognised.

This Bill also adds a new item to schedule 2. Item 11 will provide that the area comprising Iraq and Kuwait is an operational area for the period 23 February 1991 up to and including 9 June 1991. When this Bill was debated in the House of Representatives, my colleague the honourable member for Farrer, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), raised concerns about the starting date of 23 February 1991. Hostilities commenced in the middle of January and the Leader of the National Party was concerned that the operational dates therefore failed to encompass some Australians who may have been part of the initial invasion whilst on secondment to overseas units. The Minister gave an undertaking to have the dates checked and, if necessary, to move an amendment in the Senate to correct them.

Earlier today, I received from the Minister a copy of a letter sent to him by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) on this issue. Rather than read it, I seek leave to incorporate the Minister's letter in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that James Augustine O'Reilly died in Port Macquarie last Sunday and that he will be buried there tomorrow. Jim O'Reilly, christened James Augustine O'Reilly, was born on 28 August 1901. To land-holders in north-western New South Wales, Jim was a legend in his own lifetime.

PARA.TAB: Jim joined the Department of Agriculture in 1921 and became one of the best known and most loved district agronomists in the State. Jim's greatest claim to fame, apart from his innate humility and kindness, was helping to pioneer wheat growing on the black soil plains, now the real bread basket of Australia. Professor Waterhouse, of the University of Sydney, a wheat variety called Gabo and Jim O'Reilly together changed the fortunes of many north-western farmers. Actually, at that time they were not really farmers; they were graziers. Jim and Gabo came along, and the landowners got off their horses and climbed, often reluctantly, onto their tractors. I happened to be one of those persons in the early 1960s. Jim was the first district agronomist and then regional supervisor, extension, for a huge area of north-western New South Wales, including what we think of today as the prime hard wheat area of New South Wales.

I have fond memories of Jim O'Reilly. He used the local pub as his extension office of the Department of Agriculture. He taught many of us how to grow wheat there. He always said nice things about the young farmers who, in those days, were trying to learn how to farm the black soil plains. The black soil plains of north-western New South Wales are rather unique. That is why this wheat variety called Gabo came along. Gabo grew very tall —approximately five feet high.

I remember that Jim came to our property one day to judge our crop for a competition. Between lunchtime and when he arrived at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, we had a thunderstorm—they are quite prevalent in north-western New South Wales in most years, although not this year because we are having a dry time. The crop was flattened. It was lying flat on the ground. I was a new farmer and was concerned about it. I can remember Jim walk

SPEECH.PARA: ing into the crop. Before he got there I thought I was going to win the competition

with my wheat. When he got there it was only about three inches high, lying flat on the ground. He gave the nicest compliments about the crop. He said, `You won't have any trouble; it's down but you'll get it off'. And we did get it off. In those days he instilled great confidence into the new wheat growers in the area. He always made us feel better. Even when we had a bad crop in the dry years—the crop may have been only half as high, very spindly and with very small heads—he still gave us the confidence to keep going.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank Bob Kommoll, who came after Jim O'Reilly as the agronomist in north-western New South Wales, and Fred Benecke for advising me of the passing of Jim O'Reilly. Australia has lost a great pioneer of the farming industry in the north west. His untiring efforts in the 1950s and 1960s set a standard of service that may never be equalled. We will miss him. All of those who are associated with the wheat industry in the north-west of New South Wales will dearly miss him in the future.
